</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold owns its corporate headquarters in Libanon, South Africa.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The MPRDA came into operation on May&nbsp;1, 2004 and transferred ownership of mineral resources (which includes the rights to grant
	prospecting and mining rights on behalf of the nation) to the South African people with the South African government acting as custodian. Mining companies are required to apply for the right to mine and/or prospect. In November 2006, the South
	African Department of Minerals and Energy approved the conversion of Sibanye Gold&#146;s mining rights under the former regulatory regime at Driefontein and Kloof (both now part of KDC) and Beatrix into rights under the new regime. All of Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s South African mines have their new order mining rights.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold also owns most of the surface rights with
	respect to its mining properties. Where Sibanye Gold conducts surface operations, on land the surface rights of which it does not own, it does so in accordance with applicable mining and property laws. In addition, Sibanye Gold owns prospecting and
	surface rights contiguous to its operations. As required under the MPRDA, Sibanye Gold has registered its surface rights utilized for mining purposes. Sibanye Gold has received prospecting rights on properties which it has identified as being able
	to contribute, now or in the future, to its business and is in the process of converting those prospecting rights to mining rights under the MPRDA. See &#147;&#151;Environmental and Regulatory Matters&#151;Mineral Rights&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	68
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold also holds title to numerous non-mining properties in South Africa, including
	buildings, shops, farmland and hospitals, and is the registered owner of approximately 55,341 hectares of land in the Gauteng and Free State Provinces.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The maps presented below show the location of Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" COLSPAN="3" ALIGN="CENTER">
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2013/04/26/0001193125-13-177260_G475028G40D35.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" COLSPAN="3">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2013/04/26/0001193125-13-177260_G475028G39E03.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Research and Development
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold undertakes various research and development projects relating to gold production technology and potential uses of gold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	69
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage77"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%;PADDING-BOTTOM:0PX; ">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold is currently involved in the testing of biotechnology for
	the destruction of cyanide compounds in residue streams, for the purpose of complying with the Cyanide Code. The
	ASTER
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<SUP STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN:BASELINE; POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:.8EX">
	&reg;
</SUP>
</FONT>
	process is patented in South Africa. Sibanye Gold is in discussions regarding the possible disposal of
	this initiative.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<A NAME="FIS_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Legal Proceedings
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On August&nbsp;21, 2012, a court application was served on a group of respondents that included Sibanye Gold (the &#147;August Respondents&#148;). On December&nbsp;21, 2012, a further court application
	was issued and was formally served on a number of respondents, including Sibanye Gold, (the &#147;December Respondents&#148; and, together with the August Respondents, the &#147;Respondents&#148;) on January, 10 2013, on behalf of classes of mine
	workers, former mine workers and their dependents who were previously employed by, or who are currently employed by, amongst others, Sibanye Gold and who allegedly contracted silicosis and/or other occupational lung diseases (the
	&#147;Classes&#148;). The court application of August&nbsp;21, 2012 and the court application of December&nbsp;21, 2012 are together referred to below as the &#147;Applications&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	These Applications request that the court certify a class action to be instituted by the applicants on behalf of the Classes. These
	Applications are the first and preliminary steps in a process where, if the court were to certify the class action, the applicants may, in a second stage, bring an action wherein they will attempt to hold the Respondents liable for silicosis and
	other occupational lung diseases and resultant consequences. In the second stage, the Applications contemplate addressing what the applicants describe as common legal and factual issues regarding the claim arising from the allegations of the entire
	Classes. If the applicants are successful in the second stage, they envisage that individual members of the Classes could later submit individual claims for damages against the respective Respondents. The Applications do not identify the number of
	claims that may be instituted against the Respondents or the quantum of damages the applicants may seek.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	With respect to the
	Applications, Sibanye Gold has filed notice of its intention to oppose both the Applications and has instructed its attorneys to defend the claims. Sibanye Gold and its attorneys are engaging with the applicants&#146; attorneys in both Applications
	to try to establish a court-sanctioned process to agree the timelines, (including the date by which Sibanye Gold must file its papers opposing the Applications) and the possible consolidation of the separate applications. At this stage, Sibanye Gold
	cannot quantify its potential liability from this action.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other than the proceedings described above, Sibanye Gold is not a
	party to any material legal or arbitration proceedings, nor is any of its property the subject of pending material legal proceedings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Glossary of Mining Terms
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following explanations are not intended as technical definitions, but rather are intended to assist the reader in understanding some
	of the terms used in this annual report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Backfill
</B>
	&#148; means material, generally sourced from tailings or waste
	rock, used to refill mined-out areas to increase the long-term stability of mines and mitigate the effects of seismicity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Breast Stoping
</B>
	&#148; means a mining method whereby the direction of mining is in the direction of strike of the reef.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Carbon in leach, or CIL
</B>
	&#148; means a process similar to CIP (described below) except that the ore slurries are
	not leached with cyanide prior to carbon loading. Instead, the leaching and carbon loading occur simultaneously.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Carbon in pulp, or CIP
</B>
	&#148; means a common process used to extract gold from cyanide leach slurries. The process consists
	of carbon granules suspended in the slurry and flowing counter-current to the process slurry in multiple-staged agitated tanks. The process slurry, which has been leached with cyanide prior to the CIP process,
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	70
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	contains soluble gold. The soluble gold is absorbed onto the carbon granules which are subsequently separated from the slurry by screening. The gold is then recovered from the carbon by
	electrowinning onto steel wool cathodes or by a similar process.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Cleaning
</B>
	&#148; means the process of removing
	broken rock from a mine.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Closely spaced dip pillar mining method
</B>
	&#148; means a mining method where support
	pillars are left in place at relatively close intervals to increase the stability of the mine. Mining is conducted using conventional drilling and blasting techniques.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_22"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Comminution
</B>
	&#148; means the breaking, crushing or grinding of ore by mechanical means.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Crosscut
</B>
	&#148;
<B>
</B>
	means a mine working driven horizontally and at right angles to a level.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Decline or incline
</B>
	&#148; means a sloping underground opening for machine access from the surface to an underground mine or from level to level in a mine. Declines and inclines are often
	driven in a spiral to access different elevations in the mine.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Declustered averaging
</B>
	&#148; means an estimation
	technique used in the evaluation of ore reserves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Depletion
</B>
	&#148; means the decrease in quantity of ore in a
	deposit or property resulting from extraction or production.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Development
</B>
	&#148; means activities (including shaft
	sinking and on-reef and off-reef tunneling) required to prepare for mining activities and maintain a planned production level and those costs incurred to enable the conversion of mineralization to reserves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Dilution
</B>
	&#148; means the mixing of waste rock with ore, resulting in a decrease in the overall grade.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Dissolution
</B>
	&#148; means the process whereby a metal is dissolved and becomes amenable to separation from the gangue
	material.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Electrowinning
</B>
	&#148; means the process of removing gold from solution by the action of electric
	currents.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Exploration
</B>
	&#148; means activities associated with ascertaining the existence, location, extent or
	quality of mineralization, including economic and technical evaluations of mineralization.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Flotation
</B>
	&#148; means
	the process whereby certain chemicals are added to the material fed to the leach circuit in order to float the desired minerals to produce a concentrate of the mineral to be processed. This process can be carried out in column flotation cells.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Gangue
</B>
	&#148; means commercially valueless material remaining after ore extraction from rock.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Gold reserves
</B>
	&#148; means the gold contained within proven and probable reserves on the basis of recoverable material
	(reported as mill delivered tons and head grade).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Grade
</B>
	&#148; means the quantity of metal per unit mass of ore
	expressed as a percentage or, for gold, as grams of gold per ton of ore.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Grinding
</B>
	&#148; means reducing rock to
	the consistency of fine sand by crushing and abrading in a rotating steel grinding mill.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Head grade
</B>
	&#148; means
	the grade of the ore as delivered to the metallurgical plant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	71
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage79"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Heap leaching
</B>
	&#148; means a relatively low-cost technique for extracting metals
	from ore by percolating leaching solutions through heaps of ore placed on impervious pads. Generally used on low grade ores.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_23"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	In situ
</B>
	&#148; means within unbroken rock or still in the ground.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Kriging
</B>
	&#148; means an estimation technique used in the evaluation of ore reserves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Leaching
</B>
	&#148; means dissolution of gold from the crushed and milled material, including reclaimed slime, for absorption and
	concentration onto the activated carbon.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Level
</B>
	&#148; means the workings or tunnels of an underground mine which
	are on the same horizontal plane.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Life of mine, or LoM
</B>
	&#148; means the expected remaining years of production,
	based on production rates and ore reserves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	London afternoon fixing price
</B>
	&#148; means the afternoon session open
	fixing of the gold price which takes place daily in London and is set by a board comprising five financial institutions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Mark-to-market
</B>
	&#148; means the current fair value of a derivative based on current market prices, or to calculate the
	current fair value of a derivative based on current market prices, as the case may be.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Measures
</B>
	&#148; means
	conversion factors from metric units to U.S. units as provided below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_24"></A>

</TD>

</B>
</FONT>
</P>

</B>

</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	= 1 g/t
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	= 0.02917 ounces per short ton
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 kilogram per ton
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	=&nbsp;1&nbsp;kg/t
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 29.16642 ounces per short ton
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 kilometer
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 1 km
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 0.62137 miles
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 meter
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 1 m
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 3.28084 feet
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 centimeter
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 1 cm
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 0.39370 inches
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 millimeter
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	=&nbsp;1&nbsp;mm
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 0.03937 inches
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1 hectare
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	= 1 ha
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

	= 2.47104 acres
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Metallurgical plant
</B>
	&#148; means a processing plant used to treat ore and extract the
	contained gold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Metallurgical recovery factor
</B>
	&#148; means the proportion of metal in the ore delivered to the
	mill, that is recovered by the metallurgical process or processes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Metallurgy
</B>
	&#148; means, in the context of
	this document, the science of extracting metals from ores and preparing them for sale.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Mill delivered tons
</B>
	&#148;
	means a quantity, expressed in tons, of ore delivered to the metallurgical plant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Milling/mill
</B>
	&#148; means the
	comminution of the ore, although the term has come to cover the broad range of machinery inside the treatment plant where the gold is separated from the ore.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Mine call factor
</B>
	&#148; means the ratio, expressed as a percentage, of the specific product recovered at the mill (plus residue) to the specific product contained in an ore body calculated
	based on an operation&#146;s measuring and valuation methods.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	72
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage80"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Mini-longwall
</B>
	&#148; means mining that is utilized in
	geologically/geotechnically constrained areas where strike stabilization pillars are applied. The back lengths of the individual mini-longwalls are dictated by the vertical spacing of the main mining levels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Mineralization
</B>
	&#148; means the presence of a target mineral in a mass of host rock.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Notional Cash Expenditure, or NCE
</B>
	&#148; means operating costs plus additions to property, plant and equipment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Open pit
</B>
	&#148; means mining in which the ore is extracted from a pit. The geometry of the pit may vary with the
	characteristics of the ore body.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ore
</B>
	&#148; means a mixture of material containing minerals from which at least
	one of the minerals can be mined and processed at an economic profit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ore body
</B>
	&#148; means a well-defined mass
	of material of sufficient mineral content to make extraction economically viable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ore grade
</B>
	&#148; means the
	average amount of gold contained in a ton of gold-bearing ore expressed in grams per ton.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ore reserves or
	reserves
</B>
	&#148; means that part of a mineral deposit which could be economically and legally extracted or produced at the time of the reserve determination.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ounce
</B>
	&#148; means one troy ounce, which equals 31.1035 grams.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Pay limit
</B>
	&#148; means the value at which the ore body can be mined without profit or loss, calculated using an appropriate
	gold price, production costs and recovery factors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Probable reserves
</B>
	&#148; means reserves for which quantity and
	grade and/or quality are computed from information similar to that used for proven reserves, but the sites for inspection, sampling and measurement are farther apart or are otherwise less adequately spaced. The degree of assurance, although lower
	than that for proven reserves, is high enough to assume continuity between points of observation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Production
	stockpile
</B>
	&#148; means the selective accumulation of low grade material which is actively managed as part of the current mining operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Prospect
</B>
	&#148; means to investigate a site with insufficient data available on mineralization to determine if minerals are economically recoverable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Prospecting right
</B>
	&#148; means permission to explore an area for minerals.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Proven reserves
</B>
	&#148; means reserves for which, (1)&nbsp;quantity is computed from dimensions revealed in outcrops,
	trenches, workings or boreholes, (2)&nbsp;grade and/or quality are computed from the results of detailed sampling and (3)&nbsp;the sites for inspection, sampling and measurement are spaced so closely and the geologic character is so well defined
	that size, shape, depth and mineral content of reserves are well-established.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Reef
</B>
	&#148; means a gold-bearing,
	sedimentary horizon, normally a conglomerate band, that may contain economic levels of gold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Refining
</B>
	&#148;
	means the final stage of metal production in which final impurities are removed from the molten metal by introducing air and fluxes. The impurities are removed as gases or slag.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	73
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage81"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Rehabilitation
</B>
	&#148; means the process of restoring mined land to a condition
	approximating its original state.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Remnant pillar mining
</B>
	&#148; means the removal of blocks of ground previously
	left behind for various reasons during the normal course of mining.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Rock burst
</B>
	&#148; means an event caused by
	seismicity which results in damage to underground workings and/or loss of life and equipment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Rock dump
</B>
	&#148;
	means the historical accumulation of low grade material derived in the course of mining which is processed in order to take advantage of spare processing capacity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Run of Mine, or RoM
</B>
	&#148; means a loose term to describe ore of average grade.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Sampling
</B>
	&#148; means taking small pieces of rock at intervals along exposed mineralization for assay (to determine the mineral content).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Scattered mining method
</B>
	&#148; means conventional mining which is applied in a non-systematic configuration.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Seismicity
</B>
	&#148; means a sudden movement within a given volume of rock that radiates detectable seismic waves. The amplitude
	and frequency of seismic waves radiated from such a source depend, in general, on the strength and state of stress of the rock, the size of the source of seismic radiation, and the magnitude and the rate at which the rock moves during the fracturing
	process. Rock bursts, as defined above, involve seismicity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Semi-autogenous grinding, or SAG, mill
</B>
	&#148; means a
	piece of machinery used to crush and grind ore which uses a mixture of steel balls and the ore itself to achieve comminution. The mill is shaped like a cylinder causing the grinding media and the ore itself to impact upon the ore.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Shaft
</B>
	&#148; means a shaft providing principal access to the underground workings for transporting personnel, equipment,
	supplies, ore and waste. A shaft is also used for ventilation and as an auxiliary exit. It may be equipped with a surface hoist system that lowers and raises conveyances for men, materials and ore in the shaft. A shaft generally has more than one
	conveyancing compartment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Shortfall
</B>
	&#148; means the ratio of actual reef tonnage hoisted compared to monthly
	reef tonnage broken.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Sichel &#147;t&#148;
</B>
	&#148; means an estimation technique used in the evaluation of ore
	reserves.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Slurry
</B>
	&#148; means a fluid comprising fine solids suspended in a solution (generally water containing
	additives).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Smelting
</B>
	&#148; means thermal processing whereby molten metal is liberated from beneficiated ore or
	concentrate with impurities separating as lighter slag.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Spot price
</B>
	&#148; means the current price of a metal for
	immediate delivery.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Stockpile
</B>
	&#148; means a store of unprocessed ore.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Stope
</B>
	&#148; means the underground excavation within the ore body where the main gold production takes place.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Tailings
</B>
	&#148; means finely ground rock from which valuable minerals have been extracted by milling.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Tailings dam
</B>
	&#148; means dams or dumps created from tailings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Ton
</B>
	&#148; means one ton is equal to 1,000 kilograms (also known as a &#147;metric&#148; ton or &#147;ton&#148;).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Tonnage
</B>
	&#148; means quantities where the ton is an appropriate unit of measure. Typically used to measure reserves of
	gold-bearing material in situ or quantities of ore and waste material mined, transported or milled.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	74
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage82"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Total cash cost per ounce
</B>
	&#148; means a measure of the average cost of
	producing an ounce of gold, calculated by dividing the total cash costs in a period by the total gold sold over the same period. Total cash costs represent production costs as recorded in the statement of operations less offsite (i.e., central)
	general and administrative expenses (including head office costs charged to the mines, central training expenses, industry association fees and social development costs) and rehabilitation costs, plus royalties and employee termination costs. In
	determining the total cash cost of different elements of the operations, production overheads are allocated pro rata.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Total production cost per ounce
</B>
	&#148; means a measure of the average cost of producing an ounce of gold, calculated by
	dividing the total production costs in a period by the total gold production over the same period. Total production costs represent total cash costs, plus amortization, depreciation and rehabilitation costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Waste
</B>
	&#148; means rock mined with an insufficient gold content to justify processing.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#147;
<B>
	Yield
</B>
	&#148; means the actual grade of ore realized after the mining and treatment process.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	75
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage83"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
</EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
</EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>
<EFX_UNRESOLVED_STAFF_COMMENTS>
<A NAME="FIS_UNRESOLVED_STAFF_COMMENTS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D475028D20F_HTM_ROM475028_7">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;4A: UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Not applicable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	76
</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
</EFX_UNRESOLVED_STAFF_COMMENTS>
<EFX_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW>
<A NAME="FIS_OPERATING_AND_FINANCIAL_REVIEW"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D475028D20F_HTM_ROM475028_8">
</A>
	ITEM&nbsp;5: OPERATING AND FINANCIAL REVIEW AND PROSPECTS
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	You should read the following discussion and analysis together with Sibanye Gold&#146;s consolidated financial statements including
	the notes, appearing elsewhere in this annual report. Certain information contained in the discussion and analysis set forth below and elsewhere in this annual report includes forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. See
	&#147;Forward-looking Statements&#148; and &#147;Risk Factors&#148; for a discussion of important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results described in or implied by the forward-looking statements contained in
	this annual report.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	General
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are a producer of gold and major holder of gold reserves in
	South Africa. We are primarily involved in underground and surface gold mining and related activities, including extraction, processing and smelting. All of our operations are located in South Africa. Our principal mining operations are KDC and
	Beatrix.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On February&nbsp;18, 2013, Gold Fields completed the Spin-off. The Spin-off was achieved by way of Gold Fields
	making a distribution on a pro rata basis of one Sibanye Gold ordinary share for every one Gold Fields share (whether held in the form of shares, ADRs or international depositary receipts) to Gold Fields shareholders, registered as such in Gold
	Fields&#146; register at close of business on the Record Date in terms of section&nbsp;46 of the Companies Act, section&nbsp;46 of the Income Tax Act and the JSE Listing requirements. As of February&nbsp;18, 2013, Gold Fields and Sibanye Gold became
	independent, publicly traded companies with separate public ownership, boards of directors and management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Notwithstanding
	the foregoing, one member of the Board sits on the board of directors of Gold Fields. This Director is expected to vacate his Sibanye Gold directorship within the 12-month period following his appointment on January&nbsp;1, 2013. See
	&#147;Directors, Senior Management and Employees&#151;Directors&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the fiscal year ended December 2012, we produced
	1.22&nbsp;million ounces of gold compared to 1.45&nbsp;million ounces in the fiscal year ended December 2011. Production decreased by 15.4% primarily as a result of the illegal industrial action, which resulted in up to six weeks of lost production,
	and the fire at Ya Rona shaft. Over these periods, production was 15.0% lower at KDC and 16.8% lower at Beatrix. We reported gold reserves of 13.5&nbsp;million ounces as of December&nbsp;31, 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the fiscal year ended December 2011, we produced 1.45&nbsp;million ounces of gold compared to 1.67&nbsp;million ounces in the fiscal
	year ended June 2010. Production decreased by 13.2% mainly due to wage-related industrial action, safety-related stoppages and grade declines. At KDC, production was 13.8% lower due to the reasons above resulting in lower underground mining volumes
	at lower grades. At Beatrix, production was 11.5% lower due to overall lower mining grade at the North Section, lower volumes mined and a lower mine call factor.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the six-month period ended December 2010, we produced 0.84&nbsp;million ounces of gold. Over the period, production was 0.64&nbsp;million ounces at KDC and 0.20&nbsp;million ounces at Beatrix.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	South Deep Distribution
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On August&nbsp;5, 2010, Gold Fields announced a series of empowerment transactions to meet its 2014 BEE equity ownership requirements. On November&nbsp;2, 2010, the shareholders of Gold Fields approved
	these transactions at the General Meeting which included the establishment of the ESOP, the issue of approximately 600,000 Gold Fields shares to a broad-based BEE consortium, or BEECO, and BEECO&#146;s subscription for a 10% holding in South Deep
	with a phase in participation over 20 years. As part of this transaction, Gold Fields transferred the ownership of the two entities, GFO and GFIJVH, each holding a 50% interest in the South Deep mine from Sibanye Gold to a newly formed, 90% owned
	subsidiary of Gold Fields, Newshelf. South Deep
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	77
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	accounted for 0.26&nbsp;million ounces or 13.7% of production for the fiscal year ended June 2010 and 0.15&nbsp;million ounces or 14.9% of production for the six-month transition period ended
	December 2010. The South Deep production number is not included in Sibanye Gold&#146;s production above as it is accounted for as a discontinued operation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	The Separation and Spin-off
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On February&nbsp;18, 2013, Gold Fields
	completed the Spin-off. The Spin-off was achieved by way of Gold Fields making a distribution on a
<I>
	pro rata
</I>
	basis of one Sibanye Gold ordinary share for every one Gold Fields share (whether held in the form of shares, ADRs or international
	depository receipts) to Gold Fields shareholders, registered as such in Gold Fields&#146; register at close of business on the Record Date in terms of section&nbsp;46 of the Companies Act, section&nbsp;46 of the Income Tax Act and the JSE Listing
	requirements. The board of directors of Gold Fields passed the resolution necessary to implement the Spin-off on December&nbsp;12, 2012. Sibanye Gold shares listed on the JSE and on the NYSE on February&nbsp;11, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Notwithstanding the foregoing, one member of the Board sits on the board of directors of Gold Fields. See &#147;Directors, Senior
	Management and Employees&#151;Directors&#148;. GFIMSA (now Sibanye Gold) was incorporated in South Africa as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Gold Fields on December&nbsp;12, 2002.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Historical Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared using the historical results of operations, assets and liabilities
	attributable to the Sibanye Gold Group. As of February&nbsp;18, 2013, Sibanye Gold no longer had access to Gold Fields&#146; infrastructure and has consequently established its own.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Prior to the Spin-off, Gold Fields provided purchasing, corporate communications, human resources and benefits management, treasury and
	finance, investor relations, internal audit, legal and tax advice, compliance regarding internal controls and information technology functions to Sibanye Gold. The total cost of these services from Gold Fields was U.S.$8.4 million in the fiscal year
	ended December 2012. As an independent, publicly traded company, and effective as of Sibanye Gold&#146;s separation from Gold Fields, Sibanye Gold has assumed responsibility for the costs of these functions. Accordingly, Sibanye Gold&#146;s
	consolidated results of operations discussed herein are not necessarily indicative of its future performance and do not reflect what its financial performance would have been had Sibanye Gold been an independent publicly traded company during the
	relevant periods presented. Management expects, subject to the finalization of Sibanye Gold&#146;s plans, that the total annual costs for the abovementioned functions will be approximately U.S.$8.6 million in 2013. Sibanye Gold has benefited from
	certain rationalizations, including the renegotiation of contracts, following its separation from Gold Fields, which have partially offset these incremental expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Following the Spin-off, Gold Fields has continued, and will continue, to provide some of these services to Sibanye Gold and Sibanye Gold will provide some services to Gold Fields on a transitional basis
	for a period up to 12 months, pursuant to the Transitional Services Agreement. For more information regarding the Transitional Services Agreement, see &#147;Additional Information&#151;Material Contracts&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s total liabilities exceeded its assets by $965.2 million and $1,325.2 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2012 and
	December&nbsp;31, 2011, respectively. In addition, Sibanye Gold&#146;s current liabilities exceeded its current assets by $2,001.3 million and $2,727.2 million, respectively, at those dates. Included in current liabilities were $1,996.3 million and
	$2,614.8 million owed by Sibanye Gold to GFLMS (a subsidiary of Gold Fields) as of December&nbsp;31, 2012 and December&nbsp;31, 2011, respectively. On February&nbsp;1, 2013, Gold Fields subscribed for a further 731,647,614 shares in Sibanye Gold at
	a total subscription price of R17,245.8 million ($2,012.3 million). Sibanye Gold used R17,107.9 million ($1,996.3 million) of the proceeds of such subscription amount to repay the intercompany loan to GFLMS. Gold Fields subscribed for such number of
	shares in Sibanye Gold so that, following such subscription, the number of issued shares held by Gold Fields in Sibanye Gold equaled the number of issued shares in Gold Fields. As a result of the share subscription, Sibanye Gold&#146;s total assets
	exceed its total liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	78
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On February&nbsp;18, 2013, Sibanye Gold refinanced all of its debt which existed under the
	Gold Fields group debt facilities, by drawing down under the Bridge Loan Facilities obtained on November&nbsp;28, 2012. See &#147;Operating and Financial Review and Prospects&#151;Credit Facilities and Other Capital Resources&#151;R6.0 billion
	Bridge Loan Facilities&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Directors believe that this share subscription, the refancing of all its debt, in
	conjunction with the cash generated from operations and the utilization of Sibanye Gold&#146;s existing available debt facilities, will enable it to continue to meet its obligations as they fall due for a period of at least twelve months from
	December&nbsp;31, 2012, which is the latest date for which an audited balance sheet is available.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Comparability of Historical Financial
	Information
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2010, Gold Fields, the parent of Sibanye Gold, changed its fiscal year end from June&nbsp;30 to
	December&nbsp;31 beginning in December 2011 to align with Gold Fields&#146; peers in the gold mining industry. As a result, Sibanye Gold changed its fiscal year end at the same time. It may not be possible to directly compare the Audited
	Consolidated Financial Statements directly with the Audited Transition Period Financial Statements, insofar as such financial statements refer to a completed financial year. Accordingly, the discussion below provides a comparison of the fiscal years
	ended December 2012 and 2011, the fiscal years ended December 2011 and June 2010 (which do not reflect the same 12-month periods, however, no seasonality affects the reporting periods as they both report on a full fiscal year) and the six-month
	periods ended December 2010 and December 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Set out below we have included a discussion of certain financial and operating
	information relating to the unaudited six-month period ended December 2009 and a comparison of such information against the six-month transition period ended December 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Management believes that there are no factors that would materially affect the comparability of fiscal years ended December 2011 and June 2010, except for the effect of inflation affecting the fiscal year
	December 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Virtually all of Sibanye Gold&#146;s revenues are derived from the sale of gold. Sibanye Gold also derives an immaterial amount of revenue from the sale of silver, representing, less than 0.25% of revenue
	during the fiscal year ended December 2012. As a result, virtually all of Sibanye Gold&#146;s revenues are directly related to the price of gold. Historically, the price of gold has fluctuated widely. The price of gold is affected by numerous
	factors over which Sibanye Gold does not have control. See &#147;Key Information&#151;Risk Factors&#151;Changes in the market price for gold which in the past has fluctuated widely, affect the profitability of Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations and the
	cash flows generated by those operations&#148;. The volatility of the price of gold is illustrated in the following table, which shows the annual high, low and average of the London afternoon fixing price of gold:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Note:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Rounded to the nearest U.S. dollar.
</FONT>
</TD>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On April 19, 2013, the London afternoon fixing price of gold was U.S.$1,406 per ounce.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	79
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage87"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a general rule, Sibanye Gold sells the gold it produces at market prices to obtain the
	maximum benefit from prevailing gold prices and does not enter into hedging arrangements such as forward sales or derivatives which establish a price in advance for the sale of its future gold production. Hedges can be undertaken in one or more of
	the following circumstances: to protect cash flows at times of significant capital expenditures; for specific debt servicing requirements; and to safeguard the viability of higher cost operations. At April 19, 2013,&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2012 and
	December&nbsp;31, 2011, Sibanye Gold had no outstanding hedges. See &#147;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk&#151;Commodity Price Sensitivity&#148;. Significant changes in the price of gold over a sustained period of time may
	lead Sibanye Gold to increase or decrease its production in the near-term, which could have a material impact on Sibanye Gold&#146;s revenues.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s Realized Gold Prices
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table sets out the average, the high and the low London afternoon fixing price per ounce of gold and Sibanye Gold&#146;s average U.S. dollar realized gold price during the six-month
	transition period ended December 2010 and the fiscal years ended December 2012,&nbsp;December 2011 and June 2010. Sibanye Gold&#146;s average realized gold price per ounce is calculated using the actual price per ounce of gold received on gold sold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s average realized gold price
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Notes:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Prices stated per ounce.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s average realized gold price may differ from the average gold price due to the timing of its sales of gold within each year.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Production
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s revenues are primarily driven by its production levels and the price it realizes on the sale of gold. Production levels are affected by a number of factors. Total production at our
	operations decreased from 1.45&nbsp;million ounces of gold ounces in the fiscal year ended December 2011 to 1.22&nbsp;million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. Production decreased as a result of a number of factors, primarily of the illegal
	industrial action and the fire at Ya Rona shaft. Total production decreased from 1.67&nbsp;million ounces in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to 1.45&nbsp;million ounces in the fiscal year ended December 2011. These decreases were the result of a
	number of factors, primarily including wage-related industrial action, safety-related work stoppages and lower mining grades.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Labor
	Impact
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In recent years, Sibanye Gold has experienced greater union activity, including the entry of rival unions,
	which has resulted in more frequent industrial disputes, including violent protests, intra-union violence and clashes with police authorities, and has impacted labor relations. In particular, during the second half of the fiscal year ended December
	2012, a number of unions in the mining industry threatened to or went on strike for various reasons, including the renegotiation of wage agreements. These strikes impacted each of Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations and caused work stoppages and
	significant production losses. The illegal strike action resulted in 30 days lost production at KDC East and 39 days lost production at KDC West. Management estimated that approximately 116,000 ounces of production at KDC was lost due to the illegal
	strike. The illegal strike action at
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	80
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage88"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Beatrix resulted in the loss of 23 production days at the North and South sections and the loss of 29 production days at the West section. Approximately 29,000 ounces of production at Beatrix was
	lost. Further, Sibanye Gold has entered into a consultation process with the labor unions and the DMR to consider available options, including retrenchments at Beatrix following a fire at Beatrix No. 4 Shaft during February 2013 that has caused the
	West Section to be inaccessible, at current estimates, until June 2014 at least. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations and profits have been and may be negatively affected by strikes, union activity and new and existing labor
	laws&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Health and Safety Impact
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations are also subject to various South African health and safety laws and regulations that impose various duties on Sibanye Gold&#146;s mines while granting the authorities broad
	powers to, among other things, close or suspend operations at unsafe mines and order corrective action relating to health and safety matters. Additionally, it is Sibanye Gold&#146;s policy to halt production at its operations when serious accidents
	occur in order to rectify dangerous situations and, if necessary, retrain workers. During the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations suffered 48 safety stoppages, some of which were self-imposed mine closures as a result of
	safety-related incidents. During the fiscal year ended December 2011, Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations suffered 74 safety stoppages, some of which were self-imposed mine closures as a result of safety-related incidents. Sibanye Gold has actively
	engaged with the DMR on the protocols applied to safety-related mine closures. Gold Fields, the historic parent company of Sibanye Gold, conducted a tri-partite Health and Safety Summit in February 2012 along with government and labor organizations
	to promote health and safety in South Africa as part of a comprehensive effort to improve mine safety. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations are subject to South African environmental and health and safety regulations, which
	could impose significant costs and burdens, and Sibanye Gold may face claims and liability for breaches, or alleged breaches, of such regulations and other applicable laws&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Mining Grade Impact
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Both KDC and Beatrix are in their mature life
	stage and both mines have encountered lower mining grades and yields. Both KDC and Beatrix have grade or volume management programs. See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Sibanye Gold Mining Operations&#151;KDC Operation&#151;Mining&#148; and
	&#147;Information on the Company&#151;Sibanye Gold Mining Operations&#151;Beatrix Operation&#151;Mining&#148;. As a result of the Spin-off, we expect that cash flows can be utilized to extend the life of the mines at KDC and Beatrix. Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s key focus will be to maintain profitable operations and maintain production levels for a longer period of time than had previously been envisaged through increased focus on productivity. Furthermore, it will focus on realizing the
	potential that still exists in the mines&#146; mineral reserves and resources.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We expect that each of these factors will
	continue to impact production levels in the future. These are likely to have a particular impact in 2013 as we expect the next round of labor negotiations may be difficult and may be accompanied by further strikes, work stoppages or other labor
	actions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Costs
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Over the fiscal year ended December 2012, the fiscal year ended December 2011, the six-month transition period ended December 2010 and the fiscal year ended June 2010, Sibanye Gold&#146;s total cash cost
	consisted primarily of labor and contractor costs, power, water, consumable stores, which include explosives, timber, cyanide, repairs and maintenance and other consumables. Sibanye Gold expects that its total cash cost, particularly the input costs
	noted above, are likely to continue to increase in the near future driven by general economic trends, market dynamics and other regulatory changes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In order to counter the effect of increasing costs in the mining industry, Gold Fields introduced broad-based cost saving initiatives which are collectively referred to as the BPR program. This program
	focuses on identifying and realizing major cost savings on an ongoing basis to ensure the long term sustainability of the operations. See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Description of the Mining Business&#151;Productivity and Cost
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	81
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Initiatives&#151;Business Process Re-engineering Program&#148;. One of Sibanye Gold&#146;s strategic priorities relates to the proactive management of costs with a view to reduce underground unit
	cost by approximately 20% to ensure cash flow maximization.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition, to enable Sibanye Gold to increase its focus on
	providing shareholders with increased returns against the gold price, a review of the portfolio of operations and projects, or the Portfolio Review, has commenced. Its focus is on cash flow growth (not just ounce growth), and rigorous prioritization
	of capital expenditure and exploration spend based on expected risk-adjusted return on investment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s
	operations are labor intensive due to the use of deep level underground mining methods. As a result, labor represented 62%, 61% and 60% of the total cash cost during the fiscal years ended December 2012,&nbsp;December 2011 and June 2010,
	respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Negotiations with the South African mining unions in 2011 resulted in above-inflation wage increases of between
	8.0% to 10.0%, depending upon the category of employee. Such negotiations historically have occurred every two years. However, the recent labor unrest has resulted in South African mining industry participants undergoing negotiations with workers
	and labor unions outside this period. These ad-hoc negotiations resulted in a settlement proposal made by a number of gold mining companies in South Africa, including Sibanye Gold (through its former parent company Gold Fields). Through the Chamber
	of Mines, Sibanye Gold (through Gold Fields) agreed with the trade unions to an earlier implementation of a number of provisions of the wage agreement reached in 2011 that were agreed to by all parties, culminating in an adjustment to wages in the
	relevant bargaining units of around 2.5%, or R150 million, per annum, relating to changes to job grades and entry-level wages. In addition, gold mining companies, trade unions and government have set up a working group for a wide-ranging review of
	working practices, productivity improvements and socio-economic conditions in the gold mining industry, which will feed into the next round of wage negotiations scheduled for 2013. Despite the fact that returning employees will receive the benefit
	of this settlement, Sibanye Gold&#146;s employees may continue to take industrial action to protest and seek redress in connection with a variety of issues, including pay and working conditions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Power and water made up 19%, 19% and 13% of total cash cost in the fiscal years ended December 2012,&nbsp;December 2011 and June 2010,
	respectively. In the fiscal years ended December 2012 and December 2011, power costs made up 19% and 18% of the costs of production at Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Eskom applied to NERSA for a 35% average tariff increase on each of April&nbsp;1, 2010, 2011 and 2012, and NERSA granted average
	increases of 24.8%, 25.8% and 25.9%, respectively. However, on March&nbsp;9, 2012, NERSA announced a reduction in the electricity tariff increase from 25.9% to 16%, from April&nbsp;1, 2012 through to March 2013. Eskom requested an average annual
	tariff increase of 8.0% and 9.6% for industrial users for a five year period as of April&nbsp;1, 2013, of which NERSA approved an increase of 8%. Therefore, Sibanye Gold expects further significant additional increases during the next several years
	as Eskom embarks on an electricity generation capacity expansion program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Notional Cash Expenditure
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold defines NCE as operating costs plus additions to property, plant and equipment, and defines operating costs as production
	costs (exclusive of depreciation and amortization) plus corporate expenditure, employment termination costs and accretion expense on provision for environmental rehabilitation but excluding share-based compensation costs. Sibanye Gold reports NCE on
	a per ounce basis. Management considers NCE per ounce to be an important measure as it believes NCE per ounce provides more information than other commonly used measures, such as total cash costs per ounce, regarding the real cost to Sibanye Gold of
	producing an ounce of gold, reflecting not only the ongoing costs of production but also the investment cost of bringing mines into production. Management also believes that revenue less NCE is a useful indication of the cash Sibanye Gold has
	available for paying taxes, repaying debt and paying dividends and the like.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	82
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage90"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	NCE is a non-U.S. GAAP measure. An investor should not consider NCE or operating costs in
	isolation or as alternatives to production costs, cash flows from operating activities or any other measure of financial performance presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP. NCE and operating costs as presented in this annual report may not be
	comparable to other similarly titled measures of performance of other companies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following tables set out a
	reconciliation of Sibanye Gold&#146;s production costs, as calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP, to its NCE and NCE per ounce of gold produced for the fiscal years ended December 2012,&nbsp;December 2011 and June 2010 and the six-month period
	ended December 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_27"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="69%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
