<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Note:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Below infrastructure reserves relate to mineralization which is located at a level at which an operation currently does not have infrastructure sufficient to allow
	mining operations to occur, but where the operation has made plans to install additional infrastructure in the future which will allow mining to occur at that level.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Corporate expenditure
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Corporate expenditure was U.S.$10.3 million
	in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. Corporate expenditure consists primarily of general corporate overhead and corporate service department costs, mainly in the areas of technical services, human resources and finance, which are
	used by the operations. Corporate expenditure also includes business development costs. In Rand terms, corporate expenditure was R73.6 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. Corporate expenditure represents costs charged by
	Gold Fields.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Employee termination costs
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the six-month transition period ended December 2010, Sibanye Gold incurred employee termination costs of U.S.$34.4 million. The terminations related primarily to restructuring at KDC and Beatrix. In
	addition, certain employees opted for voluntary separation packages following the business process re-engineering exercise introduced in the calendar year 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Profit on disposal of property, plant and equipment
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Profit on
	disposal of property, plant and equipment was U.S.$0.4 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. The disposals related to the sale of equipment at KDC.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Increase/(decrease) in provision for post-retirement healthcare costs
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold provides medical benefits to employees in its operations through the Sibanye Gold Medical Scheme.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the medical plan which covers certain of its former employees, Sibanye Gold remains liable for 50% of these retired employees&#146;
	medical contributions after their retirement. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, 142 former employees were covered under this plan. This benefit is not available to members of the scheme who were employees of the former Free State operation (which is now
	the Beatrix operation) who retired after August&nbsp;31, 1997, and other employees who retired after January&nbsp;31, 1999.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	114
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage122"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Until its distribution in December 2010, Sibanye Gold had an additional post-retirement
	health care cost liability relating to South Deep employees. Former employees of South Deep belonged to a commercial medical scheme with employer liability for contribution per pensioner limited to R400 per month, which contribution was fixed until
	the termination of the obligation on December&nbsp;31, 2011. This obligation was subsequently transferred as part of the South Deep distribution.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the six-month transition period ended December 2010, an amount of U.S.$0.1 million was credited to earnings in respect of Sibanye Gold&#146;s obligations under these medical plans. The credit related
	to the annual interest and service charge. The post-retirement healthcare provision is updated annually based on actuarial calculations, with any increase/decrease in the provision reflected in the statement of operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Accretion expense on provision for environmental rehabilitation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	At all of its mining operations, Sibanye Gold makes full provision for environmental rehabilitation based on the net present value of the estimated cost of restoring the environmental disturbance that has
	occurred up to the balance sheet date. The rehabilitation charge for the six-month transition period ended December 2010 was U.S.$5.8 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold contributes to environmental trust funds it has established to provide for any environmental rehabilitation obligations and expected closure costs relating to its mining operations. The
	amounts invested in the trust funds are classified as non-current assets and any income earned on these assets is accounted for as interest income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Interest income
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest income amounted to U.S.$8.0 million in the
	six-month transition period ended December 2010. The interest comprised U.S.$4.0 million on monies invested in the environmental trust funds and U.S.$4.0 million on other cash and cash equivalent balances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Finance expense
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold recognized finance expense of U.S.$7.9 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. The interest charge
	comprised U.S.$1.1 million on uncommitted facilities and U.S.$6.8 million on Gold Fields intercompany loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	South African Equity
	Empowerment Transactions
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Mining Charter requires mining entities to achieve a 26% ownership of South African
	mining assets by HDSAs by the year 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the fiscal year ended June&nbsp;30, 2004, Gold Fields implemented its first 15%
	BEE transaction with Mvelaphanda, a BEE partner. During the six-month transition period ended December 2010, Gold Fields implemented two empowerment transactions to comply with the 2014 BEE equity ownership targets. The value of these transactions
	was U.S.$182.1 million comprising of the ESOP, for 10.75% of Sibanye Gold, and a broad-based BEE transaction for a further 1.0% of Sibanye Gold. For accounting purposes, these transactions qualify as share-based compensation costs. U.S.$10.8 million
	of the U.S.$182.1 million related to South Deep, which is included within discontinued operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the ESOP
	transaction, 13.5&nbsp;million Gold Fields shares were issued to approximately 47,000 Sibanye Gold employees. These shares were valued on the grant date using Gold Fields&#146; closing share price of R122.79 on December&nbsp;22, 2010, adjusted by a
	marketability discount of 25.8% to reflect the value of the restrictions placed on these shares; that the eligible employees may not dispose of the shares until after 15 years from grant date. The cost of this once-off share-based compensation was
	U.S.$171.9 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	115
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage123"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the broad-based BEE transaction, 0.6&nbsp;million Gold Fields shares were issued to
	broad-based BEE partners on December&nbsp;23, 2010. The share-based compensation cost, based on the Gold Fields closing share price of R118.51, was U.S.$10.2 million. These shares were not adjusted by a marketability discount because they had no
	trading restrictions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Royalties
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Royalties were U.S.$13.2 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Other expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other expenses represent miscellaneous corporate expenditure not allocated to the operations and therefore not included in the corporate
	expenditure line item, net of miscellaneous revenue items such as scrap sales and rental income. In the six-month period ended December 2010, there were other expenses of U.S.$11.4 million consisting of miscellaneous items which consisted of
	share-based compensation costs, research and development into mechanized mining and restructuring costs as part of the business process re-engineering.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Income and mining tax benefit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the six-month transition period
	ended December 2010, the income and mining tax benefit was U.S.$3.1 million, representing an effective tax rate of 8.9%. The effective tax benefit rate was lower than the maximum South African mining statutory tax rate of 43.0% mainly due to the
	tax-effect of a U.S.$3.9 million adjustment to reflect the actual realized company tax rate, a U.S.$10.4 million reduction relating to the South African mining tax formula rate adjustment and a U.S.$61.5 million deferred tax rate release on the
	reduction of estimated deferred mining tax rates, offset in part by U.S.$81.2 million of non-deductible expenditure comprising mainly U.S.$85.3 million share-based compensation (including U.S.$73.7 million relating to the South African Equity
	Empowerment Transactions above).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Share of equity investees&#146; profits/(losses)
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Share of equity investee&#146;s profits was U.S.$3.1 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. Sibanye Gold accounts
	for its interest in Rand Refinery using the equity method of accounting. Sibanye Gold&#146;s equity interest of 33.1% in Rand Refinery was unchanged during the six-month transition period December 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net loss from continuing operations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of the factors discussed above, Sibanye Gold&#146;s net loss from continuing operations during the six-month transition period ended December 2010 was U.S.$28.8 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net loss from discontinued operation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a consequence of the distribution of South Deep, net loss from discontinued operation in the six-month transition period ended December 2010 was U.S.$11.7 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Until its distribution in December 2010, South Deep sold 0.15&nbsp;million ounces at an average gold price of U.S.$1,287 per ounce,
	resulting in product revenues of U.S.$169.3 million, partly offset by production costs of U.S.$125.7 million. Other operating and non-operating costs were U.S.$60.0 million comprising mainly:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</B>
	U.S.$35.7 million of depreciation and amortization;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	U.S.$3.8 million net finance expense comprising U.S.$8.5 million in gross interest payments and U.S.$4.7 million in capitalized interest in
	respect of South Deep&#146;s mine development and ventilation shaft deepening projects. Gross interest payments of U.S.$8.5 million comprised U.S.$1.5 million on borrowings to fund capital requirements and U.S.$7.0 million interest on intercompany
	loans;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of the above, the loss before taxes was U.S.$16.5 million. Deferred income and mining
	taxes raised were U.S.$4.8 million resulting in net loss from discontinued operation of U.S.$11.7 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Net income/(loss)
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of the factors discussed above, Sibanye Gold&#146;s net loss during the six-month transition period ended
	December 2010 was U.S.$40.5 million.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cash resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Cash flows from operations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Although revenues from Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations are denominated in U.S. dollars, Sibanye Gold receives them in Rand, which are then
	subject to South African exchange control limitations. See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Environmental and Regulatory Matters&#151;Exchange Controls.&#148; As a result, those revenues are generally not available to service Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s non-Rand debt obligations or to make investments outside South Africa without the approval of the SARB.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash
	provided by operations in the fiscal year ended December 2011 was U.S.$870.3 million compared with U.S.$409.5 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. In the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold&#146;s realized gold price increased
	to an average of U.S.$1,652 per ounce compared to U.S.$1,590 per ounce in the fiscal year ended December 2011. The increase in the realized price only partially offset the decrease in production that resulted in revenue from product sales decreasing
	by U.S.$279.8 million from U.S.$2,301.0 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011 to U.S.$2,021.2 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. The effect of the decreased revenue on cash generated was further supported by a U.S.$76.1 million
	increase in taxation paid from U.S.$43.6 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011 to U.S.$119.7 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012 and a U.S.$98.4 million net increase in receivables being settled from U.S.$55.8 million inflow in
	the fiscal year ended December 2011 to U.S.$42.6 million outflow in the fiscal year ended December 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The net effect was a
	U.S.$460.8 million decrease in cash flow provided by operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash provided by operations in the fiscal year ended
	June 2010 was U.S.$454.6 million compared with U.S.$870.3 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. Sibanye Gold&#146;s realized gold price increased from U.S.$1,085 per ounce in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to an average of U.S.$1,590 per
	ounce in the fiscal year ended December 2011. The increase in realized price resulted in revenue from product sales increasing by U.S.$492.2 million from U.S.$1,808.8 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to U.S.$2,301.0 million in the fiscal
	year ended December 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The increased revenues were offset in part by a U.S.$129.8 million increase in production costs
	from U.S.$1,231.3 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to U.S.$1,361.1 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. In addition, there was a decrease in interest paid of U.S.$25.2 million and a higher release from working capital of
	U.S.$8.4 million. The net effect was a U.S.$389.5 million increase in cash flow provided by continuing operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the
	fiscal year ended June 2010, discontinued operations utilized U.S.$26.2 million in operations mainly due to production costs and investment in working capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	117
</FONT>
</P>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash provided by operations in the six-month transition period ended December 2010 was
	U.S.$264.5 million. In the six-month transition period ended December 2010, Sibanye Gold&#146;s realized gold price averaged U.S.$1,284 per ounce.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold generated product sales of U.S.$1,073.4 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. The revenues were offset in part mainly by U.S.$693.8 million in production costs,
	U.S.$34.4 million employee termination costs, U.S.$7.9 million in interest payments, U.S.$16.7 million in royalties and taxes and a U.S.$25.4 million net release of working capital. The net effect was a U.S.$288.7 million cash flow provided by
	continuing operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the six-month period ended December 2010, discontinued operations utilized U.S.$24.2 million in
	operations mainly due to production costs and investment in working capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Cash flows from investing activities
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash utilized in investing activities decreased from U.S.$416.2 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011 to U.S.$381.8 million in
	the fiscal year ended December 2012. The items comprising these amounts are discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Capital expenditure decreased by
	U.S.$25.4 million from U.S.$404.8 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011 to U.S.$379.4 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. In Rand terms, capital expenditure increased by R184.3 million from R2,922.6 million in the fiscal year
	ended December 2011 to R3,106.9 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. The major expenditure items were ore reserve development of U.S.$259.8 million and U.S.$295.0 million in the fiscal years ended December 2012 and 2011, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Proceeds on disposal of property, plant and equipment decreased from U.S.$2.1 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011
	to U.S.$0.6 million in the fiscal year ended December 2012. The proceeds in both periods relate to the sale of redundant mining assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold contributes to an environmental trust fund it has established to provide for any environmental rehabilitation obligations and expected closure costs relating to its mining operations. The
	amounts invested in the trust funds are classified as non-current assets and any income earned on these assets is accounted for as interest income. The amount required to be contributed each year is calculated pursuant to a statutory formula, and
	can vary depending on how the fund&#146;s investments performed, the lives of mine of its South African operations and various other factors. During the fiscal years ended December 2011 and 2012, Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations contributed U.S.$13.5
	million and U.S.$3.0, respectively, to the environmental trust fund.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash utilized in investing activities decreased from
	U.S.$604.3 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to U.S.$416.2 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. The items comprising of these amounts are discussed below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Capital expenditure increased by U.S.$20.8 million from U.S.$384.0 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to U.S.$404.8 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. In Rand terms, capital
	expenditure increased by R11.9 million from R2,910.7 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to R2,922.6 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. The major expenditure items were ore reserve development of U.S.$235.0 million and U.S.$295.0
	million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 and in the fiscal year ended December 2011, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Proceeds on disposal of
	property, plant and equipment increased from U.S.$0.4 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 to U.S.$2.1 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011. The proceeds in both periods relate to the sale of redundant mining assets.
</FONT>
</P>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	U.S.$43.3 million in dividend payments. In Rand terms, dividend payments amounted to R309.5 million.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Discontinued operations provided U.S.$47.1 million during the six-month transition period ended December 2010 and related to related
	party loans raised.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Net increase/(decrease) in cash and cash equivalents
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of the above, net cash utilized after effects of exchange rate was U.S.$108.9 million in the fiscal year ended December 2011
	and U.S.$10.6 million utilized in the fiscal year ended December 2012. Net cash generated was U.S.$17.2 million in the fiscal year ended June 2010 and U.S.$108.9 million utilized in the fiscal year ended December 2011. Net cash generated was
	U.S.$36.8 million in the six-month transition period ended December 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The resultant cash and cash equivalents at
	December&nbsp;31, 2012,&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2011,&nbsp;December&nbsp;31, 2010 and June&nbsp;30, 2010 were U.S.$34.0 million, U.S.$44.6 million, U.S.$153.5 million and U.S.$116.7 million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	120
</FONT>

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Credit Facilities and Other Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of April 19, 2013, Sibanye Gold had committed unutilized banking facilities of R2.0 billion available under the Bridge Loan Facilities.
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2012, Sibanye Gold had committed, unutilized banking facilities of U.S.$788.3 million available under the following Gold Fields Group facilities, the details of which are disclosed below:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	U.S.$730.0 million available under the various U.S. dollar committed revolving credit facilities; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	U.S.$58.3 million (R500.0 million) available under a committed Rand revolving credit facility.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Gold Fields Group&#146;s R2.0 billion Revolving Credit Facility and the R1.5 billion Long Term Revolving Credit Facilities were
	repaid and canceled on February&nbsp;18, 2013. In addition, Sibanye Gold was released from its obligations under the Gold Fields Group U.S. dollar committed revolving credit facilities as of February&nbsp;15, 2013, the date on which these facilities
	were canceled.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition, prior to the Spin-off, Sibanye Gold had access to contractual arrangements for uncommitted
	borrowing facilities with several banking counterparties to meet Sibanye Gold&#146;s normal contingency funding requirements. These uncommitted borrowing facilities were no longer available after the Spin-off date. As of the date of this annual
	report, Sibanye Gold was not in default under the terms of any of its outstanding credit facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the event that
	Sibanye Gold undertakes any acquisitions or incurs significant capital expenditure, it may need to incur further debt or arrange other financing to fund the costs which, as of the Spin-off date, may require obtaining Lenders&#146; (as defined below)
	consent under the Bridge Loan Facilities, which could have an adverse effect on Sibanye Gold&#146;s liquidity, including increasing its level of debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	R6.0 billion Bridge Loan Facilities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On November&nbsp;28, 2012, Sibanye
	Gold entered into a R6.0 billion (U.S.$700.1 million) term and revolving credit facility agreement reducing to R5.0 billion (U.S.$583.4 million) in respect of the Bridge Loan Facilities. The Bridge Loan Facilities comprise a R4.0 billion (U.S.$466.7
	million) term loan facility, or Facility A, and a R2.0 billion (U.S.$233.4 million) loan revolving credit facility, or Facility B. The purpose of the Bridge Loan Facilities was to refinance Sibanye Gold&#146;s debt on the Spin-off date, after which
	point the balance of the available amounts under the Bridge Loan Facilities was intended to fund ongoing capital expenditure, working capital and general corporate expenditure requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Facility A&#146;s loan amount will reduce from R4.0 billion (U.S.$466.7 million) to R3.5 billion (U.S.$408.4 million) on the earliest of
	the date on which Sibanye Gold&#146;s Board declares a final dividend in respect of the fiscal year ending December 2013 or the first anniversary of the Spin-off. Similarly, Facility B&#146;s loan amount will reduce from R2.0 billion (U.S.$233.4
	million) to R1.5 billion (U.S.$175.0 million) on the earliest of the date on which Sibanye Gold&#146;s Board declares a final dividend in respect of the fiscal year ending December 2013 or the first anniversary of the Spin-off. The Bridge Loan
	Facilities mature on August&nbsp;18, 2014, 18 months after the Spin-off.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Bridge Loan Facilities are provided by ABSA Bank
	Limited, Nedbank Limited, The Standard Bank of South Africa Limited, FirstRand Bank Limited and JP Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., (the &#147;Lenders&#148;) with Nedbank Limited as agent.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Bridge Loan Facilities bear interest at JIBAR plus a margin of 3.00%&nbsp;per annum for 12 months after the Spin-off and
	3.50%&nbsp;per annum for the last six months of the facilities agreement. If Sibanye Gold is not released as a guarantor under the U.S.$1 billion 4.875% guaranteed Notes due October&nbsp;7, 2020 within six months of Spin-off, by August 2013, the
	margin will increase to 3.25%&nbsp;per annum for the six to 12 month period after the Spin-off and to 3.75%&nbsp;per annum for the last six months of the facilities agreement. Sibanye Gold is required to pay a quarterly commitment fee of 35% of the
	applicable margin per annum calculated on the undrawn portion of the Bridge Loan Facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	121
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage129"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold must lodge and register a security package for its obligations under the
	facilities agreement within six months of the Spin-off if it is not released as a guarantor under the Notes at such point in time. For additional information, see &#147;Additional Information&#151;Bridge Loan Facilities&#148;, &#147;Additional
	Information&#151;Indemnity Agreement&#148; and &#147;Additional Information&#151;Cession in Security Agreement&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On
	February&nbsp;18, 2013, Sibanye Gold drew down R4.0 billion (U.S.$466.7 million) under Facility A and R570 million (U.S.$66.5 million) under Facility B and used some of the proceeds to refinance Sibanye Gold&#146;s debt under the R2.0 billion
	Revolving Credit Facility, the R1.5 billion Long Term Revolving Credit Facilities and the Other Short Term Credit Facilities. On March&nbsp;18, 2013, Sibanye Gold repaid R570 million (U.S.$66.5 million) under Facility B.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	U.S.$1 billion Syndicated Revolving Credit Facility
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On June&nbsp;20, 2011, Sibanye Gold, Orogen and GFO entered into a U.S.$1 billion syndicated revolving loan facility with an option to increase the facility to U.S.$1.1 billion within six months from
	signing date. The option to increase the facility to U.S.$1.1 billion was not exercised. The purpose of the facility was to refinance existing facilities, for general corporate purposes and working capital. The final maturity date of this facility
	is June&nbsp;20, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The facility bore interest at LIBOR plus a margin of 1.20%&nbsp;per annum. Where the utilization under
	the facility was greater than 33 1/3% and less than or equal to 66 2/3%, a utilization fee of 0.20%&nbsp;per annum was payable on the amount of utilizations. Where the utilization under the facility was greater than 66 2/3%, a utilization fee of
	0.40%&nbsp;per annum was payable on the amount of utilizations. Such utilization fee was payable quarterly in arrears. The borrowers were required to pay a quarterly commitment fee of 0.42%&nbsp;per annum.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The outstanding borrowings of Orogen under this facility at December&nbsp;31, 2012 were U.S.$666.0 million and December&nbsp;31, 2011
	were U.S.$220.0 million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Borrowings under the syndicated revolving loan facility were guaranteed by Gold
	Fields, Sibanye Gold, GFH, Orogen, Newshelf and GFO. As of February 15, 2013, Sibanye Gold is no longer a guarantor under this syndicated loan revolving facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	U.S.$500 million Syndicated Revolving Credit Facility
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On April&nbsp;17,
	2012, Sibanye Gold, Orogen and GFO entered into a U.S.$500 million syndicated revolving loan facility. The purpose of the facility was to refinance existing facilities, for general corporate purposes and working capital. The final maturity date of
	this facility is April&nbsp;17, 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The facility bore interest at LIBOR plus a margin of 1.60%&nbsp;per annum. Where the
	utilization under the facility was less than or equal to 33 1/3%, a utilization fee of 0.20%&nbsp;per annum was payable on the amount of utilizations. Where the utilization under the facility was greater than 33 1/3%, and less than or equal to 66
	2/3%, a utilization fee of 0.40%&nbsp;per annum was payable on the amount of utilizations. Where the utilization under the facility is greater than 66 2/3%, a utilization fee of 0.60%&nbsp;per annum was payable on the amount of utilizations. Such
	utilization fee was payable quarterly in arrears. The borrowers were required to pay a quarterly commitment fee of 0.56%&nbsp;per annum.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The outstanding borrowings of Orogen under this facility at December&nbsp;31, 2012 were U.S.$104.0 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Borrowings under the syndicated revolving loan facility were guaranteed by Gold Fields, Sibanye Gold, GFH, Orogen, Newshelf and GFO. As of February&nbsp;15, 2013, Sibanye Gold is no longer a guarantor
	under this syndicated revolving loan facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	122
</FONT>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	R2.0 billion Revolving Credit Facility
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On December&nbsp;15, 2011, Sibanye Gold and GFO entered into a R2.0 billion (U.S.$233 million) revolving credit facility. The purpose of
	the facility was to finance capital expenditure, general corporate and working capital requirements and to refinance existing debt. The final maturity date of this facility was December&nbsp;19, 2016. However, the facility has been repaid and
	canceled as of February&nbsp;18, 2013. The facility bore interest at JIBAR plus a margin of 1.95%&nbsp;per annum. The borrowers were required to pay a semi annual commitment fee of 0.65%&nbsp;per annum. This facility replaced a R1.5 billion
	(U.S.$175 million) revolving credit facility entered into on May&nbsp;6, 2009 and maturing June&nbsp;10, 2014 at JIBAR plus 2.95%, which was canceled and replaced with the R2.0 billion (U.S.$233 million) revolving credit facility, which became
	effective on December&nbsp;19, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold drew down R2.0 billion
	(U.S.$244.2 million) under this facility to fund working capital requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The outstanding borrowings of Sibanye Gold
	under this facility at December&nbsp;31, 2012 were R2.0 billion (U.S.$233.4 million). The R2.0 billion revolving credit facility and the R1.5 billion revolving credit facility it replaced were unutilized at December&nbsp;31, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Borrowings under the revolving credit facility were guaranteed by Gold Fields, Sibanye Gold, GFH, Orogen, Newshelf and GFO. This facility
	was repaid and canceled as of February&nbsp;18, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	R1.5 billion Long Term Revolving Credit Facilities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold and GFO entered into separate revolving credit facilities with tenors of three years. The purpose of the facilities was to
	finance capital expenditure, general corporate and working capital requirements and to refinance existing debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The borrowers
	were required to pay a commitment fee of between 0.85% and 0.90%&nbsp;per annum on the undrawn and uncanceled amounts of the facilities, calculated and payable either quarterly or semi annually in arrears.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In summary the facilities were:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	a R1.0 billion (U.S.$116.7 million) revolving credit facility entered into on December&nbsp;9, 2009 and maturing June&nbsp;30, 2013 at JIBAR
	plus 3.00%; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</B>
	a R500 million (U.S.$58.3 million) revolving credit facility entered into on March&nbsp;8, 2010 and maturing March&nbsp;10, 2013 at JIBAR plus
	2.85%
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;24, 2012, Sibanye Gold drew down R500.0 million (U.S.$61.1 million) under the R500.0
	million revolving credit facility. On November&nbsp;16, 2012, Sibanye Gold drew down a further R500.0 million (U.S.$61.1 million) under the R1.0 billion revolving credit facility. These facilities were unutilized at December&nbsp;31, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The outstanding borrowings of Sibanye Gold under these facilities at December&nbsp;31, 2012 were R1.0 billion (U.S.$116.7
	million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On January&nbsp;18, 2013, Sibanye Gold drew down the balance of R500 million (U.S.$61.1 million) under the R1.0
	billion revolving credit facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Borrowings under these facilities were guaranteed by Gold Fields, GFH, GFO, Orogen,
	Newshelf and Sibanye Gold. These facilities were repaid and canceled as of February&nbsp;18, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</P>
<A NAME="eolPage131"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Other Short Term Credit Facilities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Gold Fields utilized other uncommitted loan facilities from some of the major banks to fund the capital expenditure and working capital
	requirements of the South African operations, including Sibanye Gold. The total draw downs were R1,220 million (U.S.$149.0 million) in the fiscal year ended December 2012, R400 million (U.S.$57 million) in the fiscal year ended December 2011 and
	R290 million (U.S.$39 million) in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. The total repayments were Rnil million (U.S.$nil million) in the fiscal year ended December 2012, R400 million (U.S.$57 million) in the fiscal year ended December
	2011 and R290 million (U.S.$42 million) in the six-month transition period ended December 2010. The repayments were made from cash generated by operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The outstanding borrowings of Sibanye Gold under these facilities at December&nbsp;31, 2012 were R1,220 million (U.S.$142.4 million).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2012, Sibanye Gold&#146;s borrowings under these facilities decreased to R900 million (U.S.$105.0
	million) and were repaid in full on February&nbsp;18, 2013, by drawing down under the Bridge Loan Facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Guarantees
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition to the abovementioned facilities, Sibanye Gold is a guarantor of the following:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	U.S.$1 billion Notes issue due 2020 together with Gold Fields, GFO, Orogen and GFH.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On December&nbsp;14, 2012, the JSE approved the deregistration of the Gold Fields&#146; R10 billion Domestic Medium Term Note Program
	and, therefore, Sibanye Gold is no longer a guarantor under this program.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Note:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The contractual obligations of long-term debt is based on the terms of the refinanced debt being the Bridge Loan Facilities.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s provision for post-retirement healthcare obligations increases annually based on the expected increases in the level of individual contributions in
	order to settle its obligations to its former employees, set off by payments made on behalf of certain pensioners and dependents of former employees on a pay-as-you-go basis.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(3)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold makes full provision for all environmental obligations based on the net present value of the estimated cost of restoring the environmental disturbance that
	has occurred up to the balance sheet date. This provision increases annually based on expected inflation. Management believes that the provisions made for environmental obligations are adequate to cover the expected volume of such obligations. See
	&#147;&#151;Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#151;Environmental rehabilitation costs&#148;.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	124
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Note:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Guarantees consist of numerous obligations.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Capital expenditure consists only of amounts committed to external suppliers, although as of December&nbsp;31, 2012 an amount of U.S.$506.6 million in respect of
	capital expenditure had been approved by Gold Fields&#146; Board.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the fiscal year ended December 2012
	and the fiscal year ended December 2011, there were no material changes outside the ordinary course of Sibanye Gold&#146;s business in the specified contractual obligations. On November&nbsp;28, 2012, Sibanye Gold entered into a R6.0 billion term
	loan and revolving credit facilities agreement regarding the Bridge Loan Facilities. For more information on the Bridge Loan Facilities see &#147;Additional Information&#151;Material Contracts&#151;Bridge Loan Facilities&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Working capital
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Management believes that Sibanye Gold&#146;s working capital resources, by way of internal sources and banking facilities, are sufficient
	to fund Sibanye Gold&#146;s currently foreseeable future business requirements. See &#147;The Separation and Spin-off&#148; for descriptions of certain financing transactions subsequent to December 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Off balance sheet items
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2012, Sibanye Gold had no material off balance sheet items.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Recent Developments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Developments
	since December 31, 2011&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Trend and Outlook
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For a discussion of the trends affecting Sibanye Gold&#146;s business and operations, see &#147;Operating and Financial Review and Prospects&#151;Overview&#148;. Sibanye Gold believes that the factors
	affecting its results of operations discussed therein will continue to affect the business during fiscal 2013.
</FONT>

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:10%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Note:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Memorandum of Incorporation has been amended to include the retirement by rotation of Executive Directors. The Shareholders will be asked at the annual general
	meeting on May 13, 2013 to approve this change.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The former Directors, Nicholas J. Holland, Peter L. Turner,
	Kgabo F.L. Moabelo and Soobramoney M. Govender, resigned as Directors with effect from December&nbsp;31, 2012. Former Director Morapedi M. Mutloane resigned as Director with effect from November&nbsp;09, 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The business address of each of the Directors is Libanon Business Park, 1 Hospital Street (off Cedar Avenue), Westonaria, 1780, South
	Africa.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Directors and Executive Officers
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Board must consist of no less than four and no more than 15 Directors at any time.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The longest serving one-third of non-executive Directors, or Non-Executive Directors, must retire from office at each annual general meeting of Sibanye Gold. Retiring Directors may make themselves
	available for re-election and may be re-elected at the annual general meeting at which they retire. Executive Directors, or the Executive Directors, may be appointed as Directors by contract with Sibanye Gold for a maximum period of five years at
	any one time. The number of Directors serving under these contracts must at all times be less than one-half of the total number of Directors in office.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Board may meet as it sees fit and set its own policies for adjourning and otherwise regulating meetings. Any director may call a meeting of the Board at any time and must call a meeting if requested
	to do so by at least two Directors. The Memorandum of Incorporation further provides for the following:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	if a Director has a personal financial interest in a matter to be considered at a meeting of the Board, that Director is obliged to disclose that
	interest, must leave the meeting after making that disclosure and must not take part in the consideration of the matter. While absent from such meeting, the interested Director will nevertheless be regarded as being present for the purposes of
	determining a quorum, but will not be regarded as being present for the purpose of determining whether a resolution has sufficient support to be adopted. However, a Director who owns ordinary shares may vote his ordinary shares at a general meeting
	of shareholders in a transaction in which the Director is interested;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	126
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage134"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	a Director may not vote as a Director to determine his own compensation. The shareholders in a general meeting determine the fees for Directors, in
	their capacity as such, from time to time. Any additional compensation, including compensation for additional services performed by the Director for Sibanye Gold&#146;s business or for other positions in Sibanye Gold or its subsidiaries, must be
	determined by a quorum of Directors whose compensation would not be affected by the decision; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	the Directors are not required to hold shares in Sibanye Gold.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Memorandum of Incorporation does not provide for a mandatory retirement age for Directors. However, the Board&#146;s charter
	specifies the retirement age to be 72 years of age.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under Section&nbsp;303A.11 of the NYSE Company Manual, or the NYSE
	Listing Standards, foreign private issuers such as Sibanye Gold must disclose any significant ways in which their corporate governance practices differ from those followed by U.S. listed companies under the NYSE Listing Standards. Disclosure of the
	significant ways in which Sibanye Gold&#146;s corporate governance practices differ from practices followed by U.S. companies listed on the NYSE can be found on Sibanye Gold&#146;s website at http://www.sibanyegold.co.za.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Executive Directors
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Neal J. Froneman
</I>
</B>
	(53). Pr Eng BSc Mech Eng (Ind Opt) University of the Witwatersrand, BCompt UNISA. Executive Director and
	Chief Executive Officer. Mr.&nbsp;Froneman was appointed an Executive Director and Chief Executive Officer of Sibanye Gold effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Froneman has over 30 years of relevant operational, corporate development and mining
	industry experience. Mr.&nbsp;Froneman was appointed CEO of Aflease Gold Limited, or Aflease Gold, in April 2003. Aflease Gold, through a series of reverse takeovers, became Gold One in May 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Froneman was primarily responsible for the
	creation of Uranium One Inc., or Uranium One, from the Aflease Gold uranium assets. During this period, Mr.&nbsp;Froneman was Chief Executive Officer of both Aflease Gold and Uranium One until his resignation from Uranium One in February 2008. Prior
	to joining Aflease Gold, Mr.&nbsp;Froneman has also held executive and senior management positions at Gold Fields, Harmony Gold and JCI Limited. He is also a non-executive director of Delview Three (Pty) Limited, Hi-Zone Traders 116 (Pty) Limited,
	17 Perissa (Pty) Limited and Forestry Services (Pty) Limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Charl Keyter
</I>
</B>
	(39). BCom, Johannesburg University,
	MBA Northwest University, ACMA and CGMA. Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer. Mr.&nbsp;Keyter was appointed a Director on November&nbsp;9, 2012 and was appointed an Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer of Sibanye Gold effective
	January&nbsp;1, 2013. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Keyter was Vice President and Group Head of International Finance for Gold Fields. Mr Keyter started his career with Gold Fields in February 1995 and has held various positions in the finance department
	within the group, including Management Accountant at Libanon Gold Mine and Kloof Gold Mine and later Unit Manager Finance at Kloof Gold Mine. In 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Keyter was appointed Unit Manager&#151;Management Accounting in the Corporate Office and
	during this time he was the acting Senior Manager Finance for the Venezuela operation. Between late 2006 and 2009 he returned to South Africa and held the position of Senior Manager Finance for the Driefontein Mine and Head of Finance for the South
	African Region. In 2010, he was appointed as Head of Finance for the International Operations of Gold Fields. He has more than 17 years of mining experience. He is also a non-executive director of Oil Recovery and Maintenance Services (Pty) Ltd and
	Grease Trap Maintenance (Pty) Ltd.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Non-Executive Directors
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Timothy J. Cumming
</I>
</B>
	(55). BSc Engineering (Honors), University of Cape Town and BA (Oxon) (PPE) and MA (Oxon), Oxford University, United Kingdom. Mr.&nbsp;Cumming was appointed a
	non-executive director effective February&nbsp;21, 2013 Mr.&nbsp;Cumming is the founder and partner of Scatterlinks, a South African based company offering mentoring and coaching to senior business executives as well as strategic advisory services
	to financial services businesses. He was previously involved with the Old Mutual Group as CEO of the OM Investment Group SA, Executive Vice president-Director of Global Business Development of Old Mutual Asset Management (USA), Managing
	Director&#151;Head of Corporate Segment of Old Mutual (South Africa), Strategy
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

	Director of Old Mutual (Emerging Markets) and Interim CEO of Old Mutual Investment Group (South Africa).
<B>

	(Africa) for HSBC Securities. Mr.&nbsp;Cumming

	American Corporation&#146;s gold mines in Welkom.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Barry E. Davison
</I>
</B>
	(67). BA (Law and Economics),
	University of The Witwatersrand, Graduate&#146;s Commerce Diploma, Birmingham University, United Kingdom, CIS Diploma in Advanced Financial Management and an Advanced Executive Programme, University of South Africa. Mr.&nbsp;Davison was appointed a
	non-executive director effective February&nbsp;21, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Davison has more than 40 years of experience in the mining industry and has served as Executive Chairman of Anglo American Platinum, Chairman of Anglo American plc&#146;s Ferrous
	Metals and Industries Division and Executive Director of Anglo American plc. He was a director of a number of listed companies including Nedbank banking Group, Kumba Resources Limited, Samancor Limited and the Tongaat-Hulett Group Limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	M. Sello Moloko
</I>
</B>
	(47). BSc (Honors) and Postgraduate Certificate in Education, University of Leicester, Advanced
	Management Program, Wharton. Chairperson of the Board. Mr.&nbsp;Moloko was appointed the Non-Executive Chairperson of the Board effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Moloko was appointed as a director of Gold Fields on February&nbsp;25, 2011 and
	resigned as a director on December&nbsp;31, 2012. He is the executive Chair and Founder of Thesele Group and non-executive Chair of Alexander Forbes Group. He has an extensive career in financial services, including stints at Brait Asset Managers
	and Old Mutual Life Assurance Company (SA) Limited, where he was CEO of Old Mutual Asset Managers until 2004. Mr.&nbsp;Moloko&#146;s other directorships are Sycom Property Fund and Acucap Limited. He is Chairman of the Nelson Mandela Foundation
	Investment Committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Nkosemntu G. Nika
</I>
</B>
	(55). BCom, BCompt (Honors), CA (SA) and Advanced Management Programme,
	INSEAD. Mr.&nbsp;Nika was appointed a non-executive director effective February&nbsp;21, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Nika is currently an independent non-executive Director of Scaw South Africa (Pty) Limited, ConvergeNet Holdings Limited and Chairman of the
	Audit and Risk Committee of Foskor (Pty) Limited. He was previously Chief Financial Officer and Finance Director of PetroSA (SOC) Limited and Executive Manager: Finance at the Development Bank of Southern Africa. He has held various internal
	auditing positions at Eskom, Shell and Anglo American Corporation Limited. He was also a non-executive Board member of the Industrial Development Corporation and chaired the Board Audit Committee, and Governance and Ethics Committee.
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Keith A. Rayner
</I>
</B>
	(56). B.Com, CTA, CA (SA). Mr.&nbsp;Rayner was appointed a Non-Executive Director
	effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr Rayner is a Chartered Accountant with experience in corporate finance. He is Chief Executive Officer of KAR Presentations, an advisory and presentations corporation, which specializes in corporate finance and
	regulatory advice. Mr.&nbsp;Rayner is an independent non-executive director of Goliath Gold Limited, Sabi Gold Limited and John Daniel Holdings Limited. He is a member of the JSE Limited&#146;s Issuer Regulation Advisory Committee. He was a member
	of the committee that wrote the Takeover Regulations in the Companies Act. He is a non-practicing member of the South African Institute of Stockbrokers, a Fellow of the Institute of Directors, and a current and previous member of various SAMREC and
	SAMVAL working groups and a previous member of the Accounting Practices Committee.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

	Richard P. Menell
</I>
</B>
	(57). BSc
	(Honors), BA (Honors), MA (Natural Sciences, Geology) Trinity College, Cambridge UK, MSc. (Mineral Exploration and Management), Stanford University, California. Mr.&nbsp;Menell was appointed a Non-Executive Director effective January&nbsp;1, 2013.
	Mr.&nbsp;Menell has been a director of Gold Fields since October&nbsp;8, 2008. He has over 30 years experience in the mining industry. Previously, he has been the President and Member of the Chamber of Mines of South Africa, President and Chief
	Executive Officer of TEAL Exploration&nbsp;&amp; Mining Inc., Chairman of Anglovaal Mining Limited and Avgold Limited, Chairman of Bateman Engineering, Deputy Chairman of Harmony Gold Limited and African Rainbow Minerals and director of Telkom SA,
	Standard Bank Group Limited and Mutual and Federal Insurance Company Limited. He is currently a director of, and senior advisor to, Credit Suisse Securities Johannesburg, Weir Group Plc, the National Business
</FONT>

	Initiative and the Tourism Enterprise Partnership. Mr.&nbsp;Menell is a Trustee of Brand South Africa and a Council Member of Business Leadership South Africa. He is also Chairman of the City
	Year South Africa Citizen Service Organization, the Carrick Foundation and the Palaeontological Scientific Trust.
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Susan
	C. van der Merwe
</I>
</B>
	(58). BA, University of Cape Town. Ms.&nbsp;van der Merwe was appointed a non-executive director effective February&nbsp;21, 2013. Ms.&nbsp;van der Merwe is a Member of Parliament where she has served in various capacities
	since 1996. She currently serves on the Portfolio Committee on Trade and Industry. She was previously the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs for the period 2004 to 2010. She is currently a member of the National Executive Committee of the African
	National Congress. Ms.&nbsp;van der Merwe has participated in various civil society organisations and currently serves as Trustee on the Kay Mason Foundation which is a non-profit organization assisting disadvantaged scholars in the Cape Town area.
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Jerry S. Vilakazi
</I>
</B>
	(52). BA (Unisa), MA (Thames Valley), MA (London), MBA. Mr.&nbsp;Vilakazi was
	appointed a Non-Executive Director effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Vilakazi is Chairman of Palama, which he co-founded to invest in a diversified portfolio of sectors. He is the past Chief Executive Officer of Business Unity South Africa,
	or BUSA. Prior to joining BUSA, Mr.&nbsp;Vilakazi was Managing Director of the Black Management Forum. In 2009, Mr Vilakazi was appointed to the Presidential Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment Advisory Council and in 2010 was appointed as a
	Commissioner of the National Planning Commission. He was appointed Public Service Commissioner in 1999 and has played a critical role in shaping major public service policies in the new South Africa. He is the chairman of the Mpumalanga Gambling
	Board, Mpumalanga Economic Growth Agency and the State Information and Technology Agency, or SITA. He is the non-executive chairman of Netcare Limited and holds non-executive directorships in Goliath Gold Limited, Blue Label Telecoms, General Health
	Group (UK) and Palama Investments.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Nicholas J. Holland
</I>
</B>
	(54). BCom, BAcc, Witwatersrand; CA (SA). Executive Director and Chief Executive Officer of Gold
	Fields. Mr.&nbsp;Holland has been an Executive Director of Gold Fields since April&nbsp;14, 1998 and became Chief Executive Officer on May&nbsp;1, 2008. He served as Executive Director of Finance of Gold Fields from April 1998. On April&nbsp;15,
	2002, his title changed to Chief Financial Officer until April&nbsp;30, 2008. Mr.&nbsp;Holland has more than 30 years&#146; experience in financial management and over 22 years of experience in the mining industry. Prior to joining the Group, he was
	Financial Director and Senior Manager of Corporate Finance of Gencor Limited. He was also a director of Rand Refinery.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Kgabo F.L. Moabelo
</I>
</B>
	(42). B Admin (Honors) in Industrial Psychology, MSc in Engineering Business Management, University of
	Warwick. Executive Vice President, People and Organisational Effectiveness. Mr.&nbsp;Kgabo Moabelo was appointed Executive Vice President, People and Organisational Effectiveness of Gold Fields from August&nbsp;1, 2011. Prior to his appointment, he
	was the Human Resources Director for Africa and Levant at Cisco Systems, the IT Group from 2008 to 2010. Prior to Cisco Systems he was the Human Resources Director for Standard Bank overseeing the Global Personal and Business Banking, Credit and
	Support Services from 2005 to 2008. Mr.&nbsp;Moabelo has extensive human resources experience within the mining and energy industries, having also worked for Anglo Platinum between 1999 and 2005 and Eskom, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

<I>
	Soobramoney M. Govender
</I>
</B>
	(51). Vice President, Commercial Services of Gold Fields. Mr.&nbsp;Govender joined Gold Fields in
	February 2007 as Vice President, Commercial Services. He has extensive experience within auditing, financial management, outsourcing, sales and consulting. Mr.&nbsp;Govender implemented the Shared Services model at Gold Fields and his skills and
	competence are highly regarded in the Shared Service discipline external to Gold Fields. Prior to joining Gold Fields he held a senior position at South African Breweries.
</FONT>
</P>
