</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The business address of the persons noted above is Libanon Business Park, 1 Hospital Street (off Cedar
	Avenue), Westonaria, 1780, South Africa.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Peter L. Turner
</I>
</B>
	(56). National Higher Diploma (NHD) Vaal Triangle
	Technikon SA, Mechanical Engineering; South African Mine Manager Certificate of Competency&#151;Metalliferous; South Africa Mechanical Engineers Certificate of Competency. Chief Operating Officer of Sibanye Gold with effect from 1&nbsp;January 2013.
	Prior to his appointment to Sibanye Gold, Mr.&nbsp;Turner was appointed as Executive Vice President, Head of South Africa region. Prior to his appointment to Sibanye Gold, Mr.&nbsp;Turner was appointed as Executive Vice President, Head of South
	Africa region of Gold Fields on August&nbsp;8, 2011 and previously served as Executive Vice President, Head of West Africa since August&nbsp;1, 2009. He moved to Ghana in 2008 when he was appointed Vice President of Operations and before that he was
	the head of the Kloof mine in South Africa from 2005 and later the Driefontein mine. Prior to joining Gold Fields in 2005, he was managing director of Geita Gold Mining Limited in Tanzania from 2002 to 2005 and, before that, General Manager of East
	and West Africa Region for AngloGold Ashanti where he spent the majority of his career. He progressed through the ranks, starting as an engineering trainee at Vaal Reefs in 1975, later spending time in various managerial positions at numerous gold
	mining operations. Mr.&nbsp;Turner has more than 34 years of experience in the mining industry.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	James R.
	Wellsted
</I>
</B>
	(43). BSc (Honors) Geology, University of the Witwatersrand. Senior Vice President, Corporate Affairs. Mr.&nbsp;Wellsted was appointed Senior Vice President, Corporate Affairs of Sibanye Gold effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Prior to
	joining Sibanye Gold, Mr.&nbsp;Wellsted was a mining analyst at JP Morgan covering the South African diversified mining sector since 2011. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Wellsted was the Executive Head of Investor and Media Relations at Mvelaphanda Resources
	for seven years, until its unbundling in 2011. Between 1998 and 2004, Mr.&nbsp;Wellsted was an analyst at JP Morgan, covering the South African and African gold mining companies and contributing to JP Morgan&#146;s supply and demand and gold price
	forecasts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Company Secretary
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Cain Farrel
</I>
</B>
	(63). FCIS, MBA, Southern Cross University, Australia. Mr.&nbsp;Farrel was appointed company secretary of Sibanye Gold effective January&nbsp;1, 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Farrel was
	appointed company secretary of Gold Fields on May&nbsp;1, 2003. Mr.&nbsp;Farrel is a past president and former director of the Southern African Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Farrel served as senior
	divisional secretary of Anglo American Corporation of South Africa.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Board Committees
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In order to ensure good corporate governance, the Board has formed an Audit Committee, a Remuneration Committee, a Nominating and
	Governance Committee, a Social and Ethics Committee and a Safety, Health and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	130
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage138"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sustainable Development Committee and expects to form such committees as may be required by regulation or agreed by the Board after the Spin-off. Further, in order to comply with the statutory
	requirements of the Companies Act, the Board has formed a Social and Ethics Committee. All the committees are composed exclusively of Non-Executive Directors and are chaired by an independent Non-Executive Director. The Board may reconstitute the
	membership of the committees in the future after the completion of the Spin-off. Committees will operate in accordance with written terms of reference, which will, after the Spin-off, be regularly reviewed by the committees for approval by the
	Board, and whose duties may be reconstituted from time to time as required by the Board.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Audit Committee monitors and
	reviews Sibanye Gold&#146;s accounting controls and procedures, including the effectiveness of Sibanye Gold&#146;s information systems and other systems of internal control; the effectiveness of the internal audit function; reports of both external
	and internal auditors; quarterly and half-yearly reports, the Form 20-F registration statement and the annual financial statements; the accounting policies of Sibanye Gold and any proposed revisions thereto; external audit findings and reports, and
	the approval thereof; and compliance with applicable legislation and requirements of regulatory authorities and Sibanye Gold&#146;s Code of Ethics. On an annual basis, the Audit Committee will consider and satisfy itself of the appropriateness of
	the expertise and experience of the Chief Financial Officer. Sibanye Gold&#146;s Chief Financial Officer and internal and external auditors will attend all the Audit Committee meetings and have unrestricted access to the chairman of this committee.
	The Audit Committee, in turn, will communicate freely with other members of the Board not serving as members of the Audit Committee. To effectively perform its functions, the Audit Committee meets at least quarterly, but more frequently if required.
	Membership of the Audit Committee is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Keith A. Rayner (Chair)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Richard P. Menell
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Nkosemntu G. Nika
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Susan C. van der Merwe
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Nominating and Governance Committee is responsible for ensuring that new Directors undergo an appropriate induction process; recommending to the Board the need for Board participation in continued
	education programs; identifying successors to the Chairperson and Chief Executive Officer to recommend to the Board; developing the approach of Sibanye Gold to matters of corporate governance; and making recommendations to the Board with respect to
	all such matters. The members of the committee are:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	M. Sello Moloko (Chair)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Richard P. Menell
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Jerry S. Vilakazi
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Remuneration Committee is responsible for determining Sibanye Gold&#146;s remuneration policy and the practices needed to attract, retain and motivate high performing executives that are demonstrably
	aligned with Sibanye Gold&#146;s corporate objectives and business strategy; ensuring that remuneration levels relative to other comparable companies are pitched at the desired level taking relative performance into account. Further, on behalf of
	the Board, the Remuneration Committee reviews both the remuneration levels of senior executives and management share incentive schemes and the related performance criteria and measurements; and advises the Board on the remuneration payable to
	Non-Executive Directors (as a separate process from executive remuneration reviews) for confirmation of the Board and, to the extent required, approval by shareholders. To perform these functions the Remuneration Committee meets half-yearly or more
	frequently if required. The members of the committee include:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Timothy J. Cumming (Chair)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Barry E. Davison
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	M. Sello Moloko
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Safety, Health and Sustainable Development Committee reviews adherence to occupational
	health, safety and environmental standards by Sibanye Gold. The Committee seeks to minimize mining-related accidents, to ensure that Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations are in compliance with all environmental regulations and to establish policy in
	respect of HIV/AIDS and health matters. Membership of the Safety, Health and Sustainable Development Committee is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Barry E. Davison (Chair)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Neal J. Froneman
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sello M. Moloko
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Susan C. van der Merwe
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Social and Ethics Committee is responsible for discharging its statutorily imposed duties as contemplated in section 72 of Companies Act and the applicable regulations, which include monitoring
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s activities in relation to relevant legislation, other legal requirements and prevailing codes of best practice regarding: (i)&nbsp;social and economic development; (ii)&nbsp;good corporate citizenship; (iii)&nbsp;the environment,
	health and public safety and their impact on Sibanye Gold&#146;s activities, products and services; (iv)&nbsp;consumer relations; and (v)&nbsp;labor and employment legislation. The Social and Ethics Committee must bring any matters relating to this
	monitoring to the attention of the Board and report to shareholders at the annual general meeting. The Board seeks the assistance of the Social and Ethics Committee in ensuring that Sibanye Gold complies with best practice recommendations in respect
	of social and ethical management. The members of the committee include:
</FONT>
</P>

	Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2013, no member of the Board served Sibanye Gold exclusively. None of the current Directors acted as Directors of
	Sibanye Gold in the fiscal year ended December 2012, except for Charl Keyter who was appointed to the Board on November&nbsp;8, 2012. None of the current Directors received compensation for services performed for Sibanye Gold in any capacity in the

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Keyter. The former Directors, Nicholas J. Holland, Kgabo F.L. Moabelo, Peter L. Turner and Soobramoney M. Govender resigned effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2012. Former Director Morapedi M.
	Mutloane resigned effective October&nbsp;31, 2012. The following table presents information regarding the compensation paid by Sibanye Gold and Gold Fields for the fiscal year ended December 2012 to Charl Keyter and the former Directors.
	Mr.&nbsp;Mutloane received compensation from Sibanye Gold. However, the other former Directors, Mr.&nbsp;Holland, Mr.&nbsp;Moabelo, Mr.&nbsp;Turner and Mr.&nbsp;Govender, were employed by Gold Fields and did not receive compensation from Sibanye
	Gold or any compensation specifically arising out of their roles as Directors. Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2013, there were no Executive Officers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Notes:
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	These compensation figures for fiscal year ended December 2012 are rounded to the nearest whole number and are in Rand.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Bonuses are for the fiscal year ended December 2012 performance, paid in the fiscal year ended December 2012, as well as for shares exercised in terms of the Gold
	Fields share plans.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(3)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The compensation paid to Mr.&nbsp;Holland, Mr.&nbsp;Moabelo, Mr.&nbsp;Turner, Mr.&nbsp;Govender and Mr.&nbsp;Keyter reflects the total compensation paid by Gold Fields
	for their services to the Gold Fields Group, including Sibanye Gold, during the fiscal year ended December 2012.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Share options and restricted shares outstanding relating to Gold Fields were held by the Directors and Executive Officers. Upon
	completion of the Spin-off, individuals holding Gold Fields shares as of the Record Date received a pro rata distribution of Sibanye Gold shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">

	As of April 19, 2013, these share options and restricted shares were, to the knowledge of Sibanye Gold&#146;s management, as follows:

</B>

</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Board of Directors and Senior Management Compensation Policy
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The key principles of Sibanye Gold&#146;s remuneration policy are to: (a)&nbsp;support the execution of Sibanye Gold&#146;s business
	strategy; (b)&nbsp;provide competitive rewards to attract, motivate and retain highly skilled executives; and (c)&nbsp;ensure remuneration arrangements are equitable and facilitate the deployment of people across Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The elements of this policy are expected to include a guaranteed remuneration package, an annual bonus based on certain
	performance conditions and a share scheme plan described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table presents information regarding the
	compensation that Sibanye Gold expects to pay to Non-Executive Directors with effect from January&nbsp;1, 2013:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

	Mr.&nbsp;Holland, Mr. Turner and Mr.&nbsp;Govender resigned as Directors effective December&nbsp;31, 2012.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The above Directors and Executive Officers were entitled to one Sibanye Gold share in a ratio of one for every Gold Fields share held on
	the Record Date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	The Sibanye Gold 2013 Share Plan
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold has in place a new share plan for its employees, or the 2013 Share Plan. The new share plan consists of two equity instruments: (i)&nbsp;restricted shares (bonus shares) and
	(ii)&nbsp;performance shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	135
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage143"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The number of performance shares awarded to an employee is based on the employee&#146;s
	annual salary, grade and performance. The performance shares are expected to be settled on the third anniversary of the award date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based on the rules of the 2013 Share Plan, the actual number of performance shares which will be settled to a participant three years after the original award date will be determined by Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s performance measured against the individual performance of five other major gold mining companies (referred to as the peer group) based on the relative change in the Sibanye Gold share price compared to the respective U.S. dollar share
	prices of the individual companies within the peer group. For performance share awards to be settled to executives, an internal company performance target is required to be met before the external relative measure is applied. The target performance
	criterion is expected to be set at 85% of Sibanye Gold&#146;s expected gold production over the three-year measurement period as set out in the business plans of Sibanye Gold as approved by the Board. Only once the internal measure has been
	achieved, will the external measure (Sibanye Gold&#146;s share price performance measured against the abovementioned peer group) be applied to determine the scale of the vesting of awards of performance shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based on the rules of the 2013 Share Plan, and in addition to the performance shares, an award of restricted shares will be made based on
	an employee&#146;s annual cash bonus calculated with reference to actual performance against predetermined targets for the fiscal year ending immediately preceding the award date. The restricted shares vest in two equal parts at nine months and 18
	months after the award date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The aggregate number of Sibanye Gold&#146;s issued ordinary share capital reserved for issuance
	under the share scheme described above shall not exceed 35,309,563 shares (which represents approximately 5% of the number of current issued shares). This percentage may only be amended with the approval of shareholders in general meeting and the
	JSE.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the terms of the Gold Fields 2012 Share Plan, all Gold Fields shares vested
<I>
	pro rata
</I>
	to Sibanye Gold
	employees. The proportionate unvested options under the Gold Fields 2012 Share Plan on the date of the Spin-off were replaced with Sibanye Gold shares of the equivalent value. The unvested options were valued and adjusted at the average share price
	of Gold Fields 10 business days prior to the listing of Sibanye Gold. The options were then replaced with Sibanye Gold shares of the equivalent value based on the Sibanye Gold share price three days prior to March 1, 2013. This process was completed
	on March 14, 2013. As a result, there was an insufficient number of shares available for the annual allocation in March 2013. Accordingly, shareholders will be requested to approve amendment of the 2013 Share Plan to increase the aggregate allowed
	number of issued ordinary share capital reserved for issuance under the 2013 Share Plan at the annual general meeting on May 13, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Executive Directors&#146; Terms of Employment
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As noted, Executive Officers have been appointed effective as of January&nbsp;1, 2013. It is expected that the Executive Directors&#146; terms of employment will reflect Sibanye Gold&#146;s principles of
	the compensation policy and will be competitive with those of similar companies. It is expected that the terms of the Executive Directors&#146; employment will be as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Neal Froneman (Executive Director and Chief Executive Officer) is party to an employment agreement with Sibanye Gold. Charl Keyter (Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer) is party to an
	employment agreement with Sibanye Gold. The terms and conditions of employment for each Executive Director are substantially similar, except where otherwise indicated below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The annual gross remuneration package, or GRP, payable to the CEO and CFO for fiscal 2013 is expected to be as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Neal J. Froneman: R7,000,000
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">

	Charl Keyter: R3,500,000
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

<A NAME="eolPage144"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the employment contracts, the employment of an Executive Director will continue until
	terminated upon (i)&nbsp;12 months&#146; notice by either party for the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer or (ii)&nbsp;retirement of the relevant Executive Director (currently provided for at age 60 in the contract). Sibanye Gold
	can also terminate the Executive Director&#146;s employment summarily for any reason recognized by law as justifying summary termination.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The value of the GRP payable in terms of the employment contract is to be allocated among the following benefits: (i)&nbsp;salary; (ii)&nbsp;compulsory retirement fund contribution (with contributions set
	at 20% of &#147;Pensionable Emoluments,&#148; which are set at a rate between 50% and 100% of the GRP as elected by the Executive Director); (iii)&nbsp;voluntary participation in a vehicle scheme; (iv)&nbsp;compulsory medical coverage; and
	(v)&nbsp;compulsory Group Personal Accident Policy coverage. In addition, it is compulsory for the Executive Director to contribute 1% of his GRP to the Unemployment Insurance Fund, subject to any legislated contribution maximum at the time.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2013, Mr.&nbsp;Keyter earned R1,939,536 in accordance with his employment contract with Gold Fields
	Group Services (Pty) Limited, or GF Group Services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Other Remuneration
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition to the gross guaranteed remuneration payable, each Executive Director is entitled, among other things, to the following
	benefits under their employment contracts: (i)&nbsp;participation in the 2013 Share Plan; and (ii)&nbsp;consideration for an annual (financial year) incentive bonus based upon the fulfillment of certain targets set by the Board and an expense
	allowance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The annual bonus for the fiscal year ending December 2013 is expected to be set at a target of 65% of the value of
	the GRP for the CEO and 60% of the value of the GRP for the CFO, assuming fulfillment of all targets, with scope to award a lesser bonus if targets are not met, or a greater bonus, up to a further 65% of the GRP for the CEO and 60% of the value of
	the GRP for the CFO, if targets are exceeded.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The employment contracts also provide that, in the event of the relevant
	Executive Director&#146;s employment being terminated solely as a result of a &#147;change of control&#148; as defined below, and within 12 months of the change of control, the Director is entitled to: (i)&nbsp;payment of an amount equal to twice
	his GRP; (ii)&nbsp;payment of an amount equal to the average of the incentive bonus percentages paid to the Executive Director during the previous two completed financial years; (iii)&nbsp;any other payments and/or benefits due under the contracts;
	(iv)&nbsp;payment of any annual incentive bonus he has earned during the financial year notwithstanding that the financial year is incomplete; (v)&nbsp;an entitlement, for two years after the date of termination, subject to the relevant rules of the
	2013 Share Plan then in force, to retain and to exercise all share options allocated to him, including those which may not have vested at the date of such termination; and (vi)&nbsp;an entitlement to be settled with the performance shares and
	restricted shares allocated and awarded to him. The employment contracts further provide that these payments cover any compensation or damages the Executive Director may have under any applicable employment legislation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A &#147;change of control&#148; for the above is defined as the acquisition by a third-party or concert parties of 30% or more of Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s ordinary shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the event of the consummation of an acquisition, merger, consolidation, scheme of arrangement
	or other reorganization, whether or not there is a change of control, if the Executive Director&#146;s services are terminated, the &#147;change of control&#148; provisions summarized above also apply.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Non-Executive Director Fees
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold does not expect to have service contracts with its Non-Executive Directors. The fees for Non-Executive Directors are expected to be determined by a special Non-Executive Directors&#146;
	remuneration committee comprised of independent external remuneration advisers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	137
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage145"></A>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	(1)
</FONT>

</FONT>

	(2)

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	These employee numbers do not include contractors that are not on the payroll. As at December&nbsp;31, 2012, Sibanye Gold employed approximately 5,200 outside
	contractors not on payroll.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Labor Relations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Since 1995, the South African legislature has enacted
	various labor laws that enhance the rights of employees. For example, these laws:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	confirm the right of employees to belong to trade unions and the right of unions to have access to the workplace;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	guarantee employees the right to strike, picket and participate in secondary strikes in certain prescribed circumstances;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	provide for mandatory severance pay in the event of termination of employment for operational reasons;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	reduce and limit the maximum ordinary hours of work;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	increase the rate of pay for overtime;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	require large employers such as Sibanye Gold to implement affirmative action policies to benefit historically disadvantaged groups, and impose
	significant monetary penalties for non-compliance with the administrative and reporting requirements of the legislation;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	provide for the financing of training programs by means of a levy grant system and a National Skills Fund; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
</B>
	grant employees the right to strike if a company employing over 500 employees terminates the employment of over 50 employees at any one time for
	operational reasons.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Approximately 75% of the labor force at Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations is unionized,
	with the major portion of its workforce being members of the NUM, the other two recognized unions being the UASA, and Solidarity. As a result of its highly unionized labor force and the fact that labor costs excluding contractors constituted
	approximately 53% and 54% of total cash costs during the fiscal years ended December 2012 and 2011, respectively, Sibanye Gold has attempted to balance union demands with the need to contain and reduce total cash costs in order to ensure the
	long-term viability of its operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the second half of the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold, like several
	other South African mining companies, was affected by work stoppages at both of its operations. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Risks related to Sibanye Gold&#146;s business&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations and profits have been and may be affected
	by strikes, union
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	138
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage146"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	activity and new and existing labor laws&#148;, &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s Mining Operations&#151;KDC Operation&#148; and &#147;Information on the
	Company&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s Mining Operations&#151;Beatrix Operation&#148;. During these work stoppages, approximately 29,000 out of the approximately 36,000 Sibanye Gold employees went on strike during September and October 2012. These work
	stoppages continued despite the Chamber of Mines negotiating a settlement with NUM, Solidarity and UASA which the striking employees rejected. This breakdown of union cohesion has made, and may continue to make, it difficult to settle labor issues
	such as wage demands and working conditions. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Risks related to Sibanye Gold&#146;s business&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations and profits have been and may be affected by strikes, union activity and new and existing
	labor laws.&#148;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations suffered 48 safety stoppages,
	some of which were self-imposed mine closures as a result of safety-related incidents. During the fiscal year ended December 2011, Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations suffered 74 safety stoppages, some of which were self-imposed mine closures as a result
	of safety-related incidents. Sibanye Gold has actively engaged with the DMR on the protocols applied to safety-related mine closures. Gold Fields, the historic parent company of Sibanye Gold, conducted a tri-partite Health and Safety Summit in
	February 2012 along with government and labor organizations to promote health and safety in South Africa as part of a comprehensive effort to improve mine safety.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Wage Agreements
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	2011&#151;2013 Agreement
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As part of Gold Fields, wage increases and changes to terms and conditions of employment were negotiated with the unions every two years,
	and on August&nbsp;2, 2011, Gold Fields reached a two-year wage agreement, or the 2011 wage agreement, with UASA, Solidarity and the NUM. This agreement provided for wage increases marginally above inflation, where the majority of employees received
	increases between 8% and 10%, depending upon the category of employee. The increases were implemented with effect from July&nbsp;1, 2011. The same percentage increases applied to Sibanye Gold in the fiscal year ended December 2012. Annual increases
	for management were implemented in January 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The 2011 wage agreement further provided for a few adjustments to other
	conditions of employment, such as medical incapacitation benefits, as well as an increase in the &#147;living out allowance&#148; from R1,400 to R1,520, effective from September&nbsp;1, 2011 and a further increase to R1,640, effective from
	September&nbsp;1, 2012. Currently, approximately 40% of Sibanye Gold&#146;s labor force (excluding employees of outside contractors) receive living out allowances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In total, labor costs decreased by approximately 9% in the fiscal year ended December 2012 compared to the fiscal year ended December 2011 due to the policy of no-work, no-pay during the illegal strikes
	over an approximately six-week period in late 2012, as well as the 13% weakening of the rand from 7.22 to 8.19 per U.S.$1.00 which offset the annual wage increase of approximately 9.4%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As noted above, as part of the strike settlement negotiations, the Chamber of Mines offered a settlement proposal, within the ambit of
	the existing collective wage agreement, to the striking miners on October&nbsp;12, 2012. Under this proposal, Sibanye Gold (through its former parent Gold fields) agreed with the trade unions to an earlier implementation of a number of provisions of
	the 2011 wage agreement that were agreed to by all parties, culminating in an adjustment to wages in the relevant bargaining units of around 2.5%, or R150 million, per annum relating to changes to job grades and entry-level wages. In addition, the
	gold mining companies, trade unions and government have set up a working group for a wide-ranging review of working practices, productivity improvements and socio-economic conditions in the gold mining industry, which will feed into the next round
	of wage negotiations scheduled for 2013. Gold Fields offered the benefit of the settlement proposal agreed by the Chamber of Mines, NUM, Solidarity and UASA to striking miners that returned to work.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Benefits
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold
	provides benefits to its employees, generally including pension, medical and accommodation benefits. Employees are also entitled to a severance package if they are laid off. Sibanye Gold&#146;s own employees are generally provided with medical and
	retirement benefits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	139
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage147"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold attempts to attract and retain motivated high caliber employees through a mix
	of guaranteed and performance-based remuneration, as well as short-term and long-term incentives, and non-financial rewards relating to work experience. Sibanye Gold has also implemented company pay structuring for management employees and also for
	supervisory employees, known as the Gross Remuneration Package.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Furthermore, in order to maintain competitiveness in the
	South African labor market, regular industry market surveys are conducted to benchmark remuneration practices and to keep abreast of industry movements regarding employee benefits and non-financial employee reward and recognition programs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold provides 50% of the contributions (premiums) under a medical plan, or the Sibanye Gold Plan, for certain former
	employees in South Africa. As of the date of this annual report, approximately 126 former employees were still covered under this plan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Bonus Schemes
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye
	Gold offers appropriate bonus schemes for employees at all levels. The focus of Sibanye Gold&#146;s bonus schemes is based on specific production and safety targets as the primary drivers, with quality factors, such as cost and development, being
	secondary drivers at management levels. Bonus scheme drivers and parameters are aligned with the Corporate Annual Incentive Scheme.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Employment Equity
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under
	the South African Employment Equity Act, or the Act, Sibanye Gold has a responsibility to: (1)&nbsp;promote equal opportunity and fair treatment in employment by eliminating unfair discrimination; and (2)&nbsp;implement affirmative action measures
	to redress the disadvantages in employment experienced by certain groups, in order to ensure their equitable representation in all occupational categories and levels in the workforce. As required by the Act, Gold Fields had a formal employment
	equity plan, which was approved by its unions and submitted as part of its report to South African regulatory officials. This will continue under Sibanye Gold. The plan includes numerical targets to be achieved over a five-year period, with regular
	meetings of employment equity forums involving management and employee representatives to monitor progress against the plan. Management believes that Sibanye Gold is currently making adequate progress toward the targets under its plan and is in
	compliance with legal and regulatory requirements regarding employment equity.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Training
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold spent approximately R309 million on employee training and development in the fiscal year ended December 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the fiscal year ended December 2012, most Sibanye Gold employees participated in one or more of the numerous training and
	development programs that Gold Fields offered. Approximately 36,622 Sibanye Gold employees and 4,949 contractor employees went through the induction and skills review training program. In addition, during the fiscal year ended December 2012, Gold
	Fields introduced a new program for on-the-job training and coaching, providing further skills development at the workplace. Approximately 6,751 Sibanye Gold employees participated in team-based health and safety training, and approximately 1,328
	employees and 807 local community members attended adult literacy programs. In addition, approximately 1,423 employees were given portable skills training, in order to support personal growth and empower employees with technical skills that can be
	used outside the mining industry.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the fiscal year ended December 2012, approximately 488 Sibanye Gold employees attended
	technical trade qualification programs in the engineering domain and approximately 305 received mining qualification training. Approximately 1,983 Sibanye Gold employees received part qualifications in the form of registered skills programs, while
	in-house new skills training and short skills-enhancement programs were also offered to approximately 4,832 Sibanye Gold mining employees, 12 technical service employees and 166 metallurgical employees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	140
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage148"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold spent approximately R308.2 million on
	direct employee training and development in human resources, which represents an increase over the budget from 2011 primarily due to a number of initiatives focused on up-skilling the workforce.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold continues to provide comprehensive training to its employees, in full compliance with the regulatory requirements at the
	sites at which it operates. The training is aligned with South Africa&#146;s National Qualifications Framework, and is carried out within the ambit of Sibanye Gold&#146;s education, training and development, or ETD, establishment, which is fully
	accredited with the relevant Sectoral Education and Training Authority, or SETA, which for Sibanye Gold is the Mining Qualifications Authority, or MQA. Sibanye Gold&#146;s ETD establishment has secured accreditation and program approvals from a
	number of SETAs outside of the mining industry, and is fully certificated in terms of the ISO 9001/2008 and ISO 14000 quality management standards. In order to secure optimal workplace safety and productive work performance, Sibanye Gold exposes its
	employees to ETD interventions which significantly exceed compliance to minimum standards, in the form of additional mining and safety skills training, team-based behavioral training, and non-mining-related life and social skills training.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition, Sibanye Gold continues to focus systematically on managerial, leadership and professional development though its
	Leadership and Professional Talent Pipeline program by means of a process known as the Management Review, which is integrated with its performance management system.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold has maintained its enrollment of University Bursars and entry-level scholarships across the technical disciplines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold continues to review the performance of its human resource development, which seeks to identify further opportunities to improve the strategic and business plan. This new focus has resulted in
	changes in the approach of human resource development, with a conscious departure from the traditional training-only approach, towards a holistic talent and change management approach.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold continues to subscribe to initiatives concerning national critical skills formation, operating through various private
	sector collaborative initiatives such as the Gold Producer&#146;s Committee&#146;s &#147;Collaborative Skills Development&#148; initiative and the Technical Skills Business Partnership, or TSBP, which involves Arcelor-Mittal, SASOL, Eskom, Transnet,
	Anglo Plats and Sibanye Gold. In addition, Sibanye Gold continues to work closely with local and national government forums towards the development of business initiatives aimed at addressing youth development.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	All of Sibanye Gold&#146;s employee training activities in South Africa take account of the human resources development requirements of
	the Mining Charter. See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Environmental and Regulatory Matters&#151;Mineral Rights&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Health and
	Safety
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Health
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The principal health risks associated with Sibanye Gold&#146;s mining operations in South Africa arise from occupational and environmental exposure to silica dust, noise, heat and certain hazardous
	chemicals. The most significant occupational diseases affecting Sibanye Gold&#146;s workforce include lung diseases (such as silicosis, tuberculosis, a combination of the two and COAD) as well as NIHL. In South Africa, the incidence of tuberculosis
	in mine workers is aggravated by exposure to crystalline silica dust and by compromised immunity due to HIV infection. HIV infection is the most significant non-occupational disease impacting the South African workforce. Exposure of HIV-positive
	individuals to silica dust can significantly increase the risk of contracting tuberculosis compared with either situation alone. Sibanye Gold continues to introduce many initiatives to reduce exposure to silica dust at its underground operations. In
	addition, NIHL is the subject of numerous interventions, including hearing conservation programs, engineering controls to reduce exposure as close to the source as possible, training of exposed workers and the provision of hearing protection devices
	to exposed workers. Sibanye Gold continues to expand initiatives to address HIV infection and AIDS among its workforce.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	141
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage149"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold provides free healthcare to a substantial portion of its employees while they
	are employed by Sibanye Gold. This includes the operation of hospitals and/or clinics to provide treatment as needed. In addition, statutory medical surveillance of all employees at the South African operations is conducted by Sibanye Gold&#146;s
	in-house health services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	HIV/AIDS
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Currently, management estimates that the prevalence of HIV is approximately 18% for Sibanye Gold&#146;s employees. Sibanye Gold believes that its workforce has a similar level of HIV prevalence to that
	present in the same demographic groups in South Africa generally. Accordingly, Sibanye Gold has developed and implemented a significant HIV/AIDS program with the goals of reducing the rate of HIV infection among its workforce and minimizing the
	potential financial impact of AIDS on its operations. This program involves a multi-faceted approach known as the HAST program (HIV, AIDS, sexually transmitted infections and tuberculosis), which consists of a variety of initiatives aimed at
	preventing these diseases and includes collaboration with international organizations such as the Global Health Initiative, World Economic Forum, World Health Organization and USAID. In addition to these programs, care and support for workers with
	HIV/AIDS includes wellness management, ill health retirement for workers with AIDS and home-based care for such workers following retirement. See &#147;Risk Factors&#151;Risks related to South Africa&#151;HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and other contagious
	diseases pose risks to Sibanye Gold in terms of lost productivity and increased costs&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Safety
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Operating mines, particularly underground mines, involves significant safety hazards. Sibanye Gold takes steps to address particular
	safety issues which are present at its operations. Specific safety issues are explained in further detail in connection with the description of each of Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations. See &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s
	Mining Operations&#151;KDC Operation&#151;Mining&#148; and &#147;Information on the Company&#151;Sibanye Gold&#146;s Mining Operations&#151;Beatrix Operation&#151;Mining&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During the fiscal year ended December 2012, Sibanye Gold faced a number of significant safety issues, including the deaths of 16 workers
	at its mines. Sibanye Gold continually renews its commitment to safety. OHSAS 18001 surveillance audits were conducted by Burea Veritas at Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations. Non-conforming practices identified during the audits have been rectified and
	certification has been maintained at all operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s Full Compliance Health and Safety Management System
	started as a health and safety initiative at the end of 2000. A group consisting of representatives of management, the DMR&#146;s Mine Health and Safety inspectorate and South African trade unions developed the management system for Sibanye Gold.
	The Full Compliance Health and Safety Management System consists of health and safety management standards aimed at improving the safety performance of each mine. Every year the system is revisited, taking into consideration recent fatal accidents,
	lessons learned from the investigations and the outcomes of the various safety audits that have been conducted. Safety training initiatives at the South African operations are tailored for these particular circumstances. All employees undergo
	refresher training at least once a year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the fiscal year ended June 2010, in order to further safety-improvement efforts,
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s Safe Production Management strategy was re-focused on two key efforts: compliance and engineering out risk. These efforts were further implemented in the fiscal year ended December 2012, and Sibanye Gold intends to continue
	carrying out this safety-improvement strategy through its well-being program and leadership and skills development. The existing health and safety strategy focuses on five elements: culture, stakeholder engagement, well-being, engineering out risk
	and compliance. This approach was project managed in 2012 to bring about the required shift in health and safety attitudes, practices and procedures. Bain&nbsp;&amp; Company was engaged for the first half of 2012 to assist with the implementation of
	the safety strategy, as well as its culture transformation program. Thereafter, Sibanye Gold has continued implementing the programs in the second half of 2012 and to date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	142
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage150"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D475028D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s operations have subscribed to the milestones set for accidents,
	silicosis and NIHL issued by the MHSC, which is a legislative body set up under the Mine Health and Safety Act to advise the Minister of Mineral Resources on mine health and safety legislation. These milestones include: (i)&nbsp;achieving safety
	performance levels equivalent to international standards for underground metalliferous mines by 2013; (ii)&nbsp;by December 2008, achieving respirable crystalline silica levels of below 0.1 mg per cubic meter in 95% of individual exposure
	measurement results; (iii)&nbsp;after December 2013, there being no new cases of silicosis among individuals previously unexposed prior to 2008; (iv)&nbsp;after December 2008, eliminating hearing deterioration by more than 10% among occupationally
	exposed individuals; and (v)&nbsp;by December 2013, reducing the noise emitted by equipment to a level below 110dBA at any location in the workplace. As of December&nbsp;31, 2012, Sibanye Gold measured respirable crystalline silica levels below 0.1
	mg per cubic meter in 96.5% of exposure measurement results, and 1.1% of the equipment measurements taken were at or above 110 dBA. Silencing of equipment is ongoing, with continued focus on replacing blocked and/or damaged silencers on machines.
	South Africa has a legislated personal OEL of 85 dBA. Both the DMR and the Chamber of Mines accept the use of hearing devices while methods for reducing hearing loss are explored. As of December 31, 2012, the percentage of employees exposed above 85
	dBA was 45.8%. This measurement is without ear protection. Studies indicate that with the proper use of currently available ear protection devices no employee will be subject to a sound pressure level in excess of 85 dBA when exposed to less than
	105 dBA. A project to measure exposure while using hearing protective devices to provide further verification was started in September 2012 and is ongoing. Cases of NIHL and silicosis may still arise in the future, particularly due to the latency
	period after exposure. Sibanye Gold has also set internal targets, which are more stringent than these milestones.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

	Lost Time Injury
	Frequency Rate and Fatal Injury Frequency Rate
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following tables set out the lost time injury frequency rate and fatal
	injury frequency rate data for KDC and Beatrix for the last five calendar years.
</FONT>
</P>

	Major Shareholders
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2012, the issued share capital of Sibanye Gold consisted of 1,000 ordinary shares, all of which were held by Gold Fields. As of April 19, 2013, the issued share capital of Sibanye
	Gold consisted of 732,085,031ordinary shares.
</FONT>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To our knowledge: (1)&nbsp;Sibanye Gold is not directly or indirectly owned or
	controlled (a)&nbsp;by another corporation or (b)&nbsp;by any foreign government; and (2)&nbsp;there are no arrangements the operation of which may at a subsequent date result in a change in control of Sibanye Gold. To the knowledge of Sibanye
	Gold&#146;s management, there is no controlling shareholder of Sibanye Gold.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the three fiscal years prior to February&nbsp;18, 2013, the entire issued share capital of Sibanye
	Gold was held by Gold Fields, and there were no significant changes in the percentage of ownership to the knowledge of Sibanye Gold&#146;s management. In anticipation of the Spin-off, Gold Fields converted the authorized and issued share capital of
	Sibanye Gold from shares with par value to no par value shares and increased the authorized share capital by the creation of an additional 999,999,000 ordinary shares with no par value. On February&nbsp;1, 2013, Gold Fields subscribed for further
	shares in Sibanye Gold at a subscription price of R17,234.8 million. On February&nbsp;18, 2013, all of the Sibanye Gold shares, including those subscribed for by Gold Fields, were distributed by Gold Fields to its shareholders in the Spin-off. See
	&#147;The Offer and Listing&#151;Listing Details&#151;Mechanics of the Spin-off&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To the knowledge of management, none
	of the above shareholders hold voting rights which are different from those held by Sibanye Gold&#146;s other shareholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Shareholders&#146; Register
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The principal non-United States trading market for the ordinary shares of Sibanye Gold is the JSE Limited, on which they trade under the symbol &#147;SGL&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Sibanye Gold&#146;s American depositary shares, or ADSs, trade in the United States on the NYSE under the symbol &#147;SBGL&#148;. The
	ADRs representing the ADSs were issued by the Bank of New York Mellon, or BNYM, as Depositary. Each ADS represents four ordinary shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2012, Gold Fields held all of Sibanye Gold&#146;s 1,000 ordinary shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For more information on the listing, please see &#147;The Offer and Listing&#151;Listing Details&#151;Mechanics of the Spin-off&#148;.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

	Public Takeover Offers
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	No public takeover offers by third parties have
	been made in respect of Sibanye Gold&#146;s shares or by Sibanye Gold in respect of other companies&#146; shares during the last and current fiscal year.
</FONT>
</P>
